editionStmt.edition: This early release includes some 500 EEBO-TCP transcriptions of Early Modern plays that have undergone several routines to create an interoperable and algorithmically amenable corpus of Early Modern Drama. Many incompletely or incorrectly transcribed words have been corrected, including obvious printers' errors, but the text has not been proofread word by word. Each word in the text has been identified as a distinct token with its own xml:id and assigned to a lemma, a part of speech, and a standard spelling. Speech prefixes were mapped to unique speaker ID's as "who" attributes of sp elements. elements

respStmt.name: Melina Yeh

respStmt.name: Philip R. Burns

respStmt.resp: With the help of Thomas L. Berger's Index of Characters in Early Modern English Drama Printed Plays, 1500-1660 speech prefixes were mapped to unique "who" attributes of sp elements by
respStmt.name: Martin Mueller

respStmt.name: Martin Mueller

respStmt.name: Martin Mueller

div.p: The Puritan or the widow of Watlingstreet.
Acted by the children of Paul's.
Imprinted at London by G. eld. 1607.

div.head: Actus primus.
div.stage: Enter the lady Widdow-plus, her two daughters Frank and Moll, her husband's brother an old knight sir Godfrey, with her son and heir master Edmond, all in morning apparel, Edmond in a cypress hat. The widow wringing her hands, and bursting out into a passion, as newly come from the burial of her husband.

sp.speaker: Widow.
sp.p: O, that ever I was born, that ever I was born!

sp.speaker: Sir Godfrey.
sp.p: Nay good sister, dear sister, sweet sister, be of good comfort, show yourself a woman, now or never.

sp.speaker: Widow
sp.p: O, I have lost the dearest man. I have buried the sweetest husband that ever lay by woman.

sp.speaker: Sir God.
sp.p: Nay give him his due he was indeed an honest, virtuous, discreet wise-man, — he was my brother, as right, as right.

sp.speaker: Widow
sp.p: O, I shall never forget him, never forget him, he was a man so well given to a woman — o:

sp.speaker: Sir Godf.
sp.p: Nay but kind sister, I could weep as much as any woman, but alas our tears cannot call him again: methinks you are well read sister, and know that death is as common as homo a common name to all men; — a man shall be taken when he's making water, — nay, did not the learned parson master Pigman tell us e'en now, that all flesh is frail, we are born to die, man has but a time: with such like deep and profound persuasions, as he is a rare fellow you know and an excellent reader: and for example, (As there are examples abundance,) did not sir Humphrey bubble die tother day there's a lusty widow, why she cried not above half an houe-for shame, for shame: then followed him old master fulsome the usurer, there's a wise widow, why she cried never a whit at all.

sp.speaker: Widow
sp.p: O rank not me with those wicked women, I had a husband outshined 'em all.

sp.speaker: Sir Godf.
sp.p: I that he did ifaith, he outshined 'em all.

sp.speaker: Widow
sp.p: Dost thou stand there and see us all weep, and not once shed a tear for thy father's death? o thou ungracious son and heir thou:

sp.speaker: Edm,
sp.p: Troth mother I should not weep I'm sure; I am passed a child I hope, to make all my old school fellows laugh at me; I should be mocked, so I should; pray let one of my sisters weep for me, I'll laugh as much for her another time?

sp.speaker: Widow
sp.p: O thou past-grace thou, out of my sight, thou graceless imp, thou grievest me more than the death of thy father? o thou stubborn only son? hadst thou such an honest man to thy father — that would deceive all the world to get riches for thee, and canst thou not afford a little sa't water? he that so wisely did quite overthrow the right heir of those lands, which now you respect not up every morning betwixt four and five so duly at Westminster hall every termtime, with all his cards and writings, for thee thou wicked Absolon — o dear husband!

sp.speaker: Edm.
sp.p: Weep? quotha? I protest I am glad he's churched? for now he's gone I shall spend in quiet?

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: Dear mother; pray cease, half your tears suffice,
'Tis time for you to take truce with your eyes,
Let me weep now?

sp.speaker: Widow
sp.p: O such a dear knight! such a sweet husband have I lost, have I lost? — if blessed be the corse the rain rains upon, he had it pouring down?

sp.speaker: Sir Godf,
sp.p: Sister? be of good cheer, we are all mortal ourselves, I come upon you freshly, I near speak without comfort, hear me what I shall say; — my brother has left you wealthy, you're rich.

sp.speaker: Widow
sp.p: Oh!

sp.speaker: Sir Godf.
sp.p: I say you're rich? you are also fair.

sp.speaker: Widow
sp.p: Oh!

sp.speaker: Sir Godf.
sp.p:
Go too you're fair you cannot smother it, beauty will come to light; nor are your years so far entered with you; but that you will be sought after; and may very well answer another husband; the world is full of fine gallants,
choice enough sister, — for what should we do with all our knights I pray? but to marry rich widows, wealthy citizens' widows; lusty fair — browed ladies; go too, be of good comfort I say leave snobbing and weeping — yet my brother was a kind hearted man — I would not have the elf see me now? — come pluck up a woman's heart — here stands your daughters, who be well estated, and at maturity will also be enquired after with good husbands, so all these tears shall be soon dried up and a better world than ever — what? Woman? you must not weep still? he's dead he's buried — yet I cannot choose but weep for him!

sp.speaker: Widow
sp.l: Marry again! no! let me be buried quick then!
And that same part of choir whereon I tread
To such intent, oh may it be my grave;
And that the priest may 〈◊〉 his wedding prayers,
E'en with a breath, to 〈◊〉 all dust and ashes;
sp.p: O, out of a million of millions, I should ne'er find such a husband, he was unmatchable, — unmatchable? nothing was so hot, nor too dear for me, I could not speak of that one thing that I had not, beside I had keys of all, kept all, received all, had money in my purse, spent what I would, went abroad when I would, came home when I would, and did all what I would? O — my sweet husband; I shall never have the like?

sp.speaker: Sir Godf
sp.p: Sister? ne'er say so; he was an honest brother of mine, and so, and you may light upon one as honest again, or one, as honest again may light upon you, that's the properer phrase indeed?

sp.speaker: Widow
sp.l: Never? o if you love me urge it not,
O may I be the byword of the world,
The common talk at table in the mouth
Of every groom and waiter, if e'er more
I entertain the carnal suit of man?

sp.speaker: Mol.
sp.l: I must kneel down for fashion too?

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.l: And I, whom never man as yet hath scaled
E'en in this depth of general sorrow, vow
never to marry, to sustain such loss
As a dear husband seems to be, once dead?

sp.speaker: Mol.
sp.l: I loved my father well too; but to say,
Nay now, I would not marry for her death?
Sure I should speak false Latin; should I not?
I'd as soon vow never to come in bed.
Tut? Women must live by th' quick, and not by th' dead.

sp.speaker: Widow
sp.l: Dear copy of my husband, o let me kiss thee:
How like him is their model? their brief picture
Quickens my tears: my sorrows are renewed
At their fresh sight?

sp.speaker: Sir Godf.
sp.p: Sister —

sp.speaker: Widow
sp.l: Away,
All honesty with him is turned to clay,
O my sweet husband, o —

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: My dear father?

sp.speaker: Mol.
sp.p: Here's a puling indeed! I think my mother weeps for all the women that ever buried husbands: for if from time to time all the widowers tears in England had been bottled up, I do not think all would have filled a three-half-penny bottle; alas a small matter bucks a handkercher, — and sometimes the spittle stands to nigh saint Thomas a waterings; well, I can mourn in good sober sort as well as another? but where I spend one tear for a dead father, I could give twenty kisses for a quick husband.

sp.speaker: Sir Godf.
sp.p: Well, go thy ways old sir Godfrey, and thou mayst be proud on't, thou hast a kind loving sister-in-law; how constant? how passionate? how full of April the poor soul's eyes are; well, I would my brother knew on't, he should then know what a kind wife he had left behind him; truth and 'twere not for shame that the neighbours at th' next garden should hear me ▪ between joy and grief, I should e'en cry outright!

sp.speaker: Edmund.
sp.p:
So, a fair riddance, my father's laid in dust his coffin and he is like a whole-meat-pie, and the worms will cut him up shortly; farewell old dad, farewell. I'll be curbed in no more, I perceive a some and heir may quickly be made
a fool and he will be one, but I'll take another order; — now she would have me weep for him forsooth, and why? because he cozened the right heir being a fool, and bestowed those lands upon me his eldest son; and therefore I must weep for him ha, ha; why all the world knows as long as 'twas his pleasure to get me, 'twas his duty to get for me: I know the law in that point no attorney can gull me; well, my uncle is an old ass, and an 〈◊〉 coxcomb, I'll rule the roast myself, I'll be kept under no more, I know what I may do well enough by my father's copy: the law's in mine own hands now: nay now I know my strength, I'll be strong enough for my mother I warrant you?

div.stage: Enter George Py-bord a scholar and a citizen and unto him an old soulder, Peter skirmish.

sp.speaker: Pye.
sp.p: What's to be done now? old lad of war; thou that wert wont to be as hot as a turnspit, as nimble as a fencer, and as lousy as a schoolmaster; now thou art put to silence like a sectary? — war sits now like a justice of peace, and does nothing, where be your muskets, calivers and hotshots? in Long-lane, at pawn, at pawn; — now keys, are your only guns, key-guns, key-guns, and bawds the gunners, — who are your sentinels in peace, and stand ready charged to give warning; with hems, hums, and pockey-coughs; only your chambers are licenced to play upon you, and drabs enough to give fire to 'em.

sp.speaker: Skir.
sp.p: Well, I cannot tell, but I am sure it goes wrong with me, for since the cessure of the wars, I have spent above a hundred crowns out a purse: I have been a soldier any time this forty years, and now I perceive an old soldier, and an old courtier have both one destiny, and in the end turn both into hobnails.

sp.speaker: Pie.
sp.p: Pretty mystery for a beggar, for indeed a hobnail is the true emblem of a beggar's shoe-sole;

sp.speaker: Skir.
sp.p:
I will not say but that war is a bloodsucker, and so; but in my conscience, (As there is no soldier but has a piece of one, though it be full of holes like a shot ancient, no matter, 'twill serve to swear by) in my conscience, I think some kind of
peace, has more hidden oppressions, and violent heady sins, (The looking of a gentle nature) then a professed war.

sp.speaker: Pye.
sp.p: Troth, and for mine own part, I am a poor gentleman, and a scholar, I have been matriculated in the university, wore out six gowns there, seen some fools, and some scholars, some of the city, and some of the country, kept order, went bareheaded over the quadrangle, eat my commons with a good stomach, and battled with discretion; at last, having done many slights and tricks to maintain my wit in use (As my brain would never endure me to be idle,) I was expelled the university, only for stealing a cheese out of Jesus college.

sp.speaker: Skir.
sp.p: Is't possible?

sp.speaker: Pye.
sp.p: Oh! there was one Welshman (God forgive him) pursued it hard; and never left, till I turned my staff towards London, where when I came, all my friends were pit-holed, gone to graves, (As indeed there was but a few left before) then was I turned to my wits, to shift in the world, to tower among sons and heirs, and fools, and gulls, and lady's eldest sons, to work upon nothing, to feed out of flint, and ever since has my belly been much beholding to my brain: but now to return to you old skirmish. I say as you say, and for my part wish a turbulency in the world, for I have nothing to lose but my wits, and I think they are as mad as they will be: and to strengthen your argument the more, I say an honest wart, is better than a bawdy peace: as touching my profession; the multiplicity of scholars, hatched, and nourished, in the idle calms of peace, makes 'em like fishes one devour another; and the community of learning has so played upon affections, and thereby almost religion is come about to fantasy, and discredited by being too much spoken off — in so many and mean mouths, I myself being a scholar and a graduate, have no other comfort by my learning, but the affliction of my words, to know how scholarlike to name what I want, and can call myself a beggar both in Greek and Latin, and therefore not to cog with peace, I'll not be afraid to say, 'tis a great breeder, but a barren nourisher: a great-getter of children, which must either be thieves or richmen, knaves or beggars.

sp.speaker: Skirmish.
sp.p: Well, would I had been born a knave then, when I was born a beggar, for if the truth were known, I think I was begotten when my father had never a penny in his purse.

sp.speaker: Pye.
sp.p: Puh, faint not old skirmish, let this warrant thee, facilis descensus auerni, 'tis an easy journey to a knave, thou mayst be a knave when thou wilt; and peace is a good madam to all other professions, and an arrant drab to us, let us handle her accordingly, and by our wits thrive in despite of her; for since the law lives by quarrels, the courtier by smooth good-morrows, and every profession makes itself greater by imperfections, why not we then by shifts, wiles, and forgeries? and seeing our brains are our only patrimonies, let's spend with judgement, not like a desperate son and heir, but like a sober and discreet templar, — one that will never march beyond the bounds of his allowance, and for our thriving means, thus, I myself will put on the deceit of a fortune-teller, a fortune-teller.

sp.speaker: Skirm.
sp.p: Very proper.

sp.speaker: Pye.
sp.p: And you of a figure-caster, or a conjurer.

sp.speaker: Skir.
sp.p: A conjurer.

sp.speaker: Pye.
sp.p: Let me alone, I'll instruct you, and teach you to deceive all eyes, but the devils.

sp.speaker: Skir.
sp.p: O ay, for I would not deceive him and I could choose, of all others.

sp.speaker: Pye.
sp.p: Fear not I warrant you; and so by those means we shall help one another to patients, as the condition of the age affords creatures enough for cunning to work upon.

sp.speaker: Skir.
sp.p: O wondrous new fools and fresh asses.

sp.speaker: Pye.
sp.p: O, fit, fit, excellent.

sp.speaker: Skir.
sp.p: What in the name of conjuring?

sp.speaker: Pye-boord.
sp.p: My memory greets me happily with an admirable subject to graze upon. The lady-widow, who of late I saw weeping in her garden for the death of her husband, sure she as but a waterish soul, and half on't by this time is dropped out of her lies: device well managed may do good upon her: it stands firm, my first practice shall be there?

sp.speaker: Skir.
sp.p: You have my voice George?

sp.speaker: Pye-boord.
sp.p: Sh'as a grey gall to her brother, a fool to her only son, and an ape to her youngest daughter; — I overheard 'em severally, and from their words I'll derive my device; and thou old Peter skirmish shall be my second in all slights.

sp.speaker: Skir.
sp.p: Ne'er doubt me George Pie-board. — only you must teach me to conjure.

div.stage: Enter captain idle, pinioned, and with a guard of officers passeth over the stage.

sp.speaker: Pye.
sp.l: Push, I'll perfect thee, Peter:
How now? what's he?

sp.speaker: Skir.
sp.l: O George! this sight kills me,
'Tis my sworn brother, captain idle.

sp.speaker: Pye.
sp.p: Captain idle.

sp.speaker: Skir.
sp.p: Apprehended for some felonious act or other, he has started out, has made a night on't, lacked silver; I cannot but commend his resolution, he would not pawn his buff-jerkin, I would either some of us were employed, or might pitch our tents at usurer's doors, to kill the slaves as they peep out at the wicket.

sp.speaker: Pye.
sp.p: Indeed those are our ancient enemies; they keep our money in their hands, and make us to be hanged for robbing of 'em, but come let's follow after to the prison, and know the nature of his offence, and what we can steed him in, he shall be sure of; and I'll uphold it still, that a charitable knave, is better than a soothing Puritan.

div.stage: Enter at one door corporal oath, a vainglorious fellow, and at the other, three of the widow Puritaines serving-men, Nicholas Saint-tantlings, Simon Saint-mary-oueries, and Frailtie in black scurvy mourning coats, and books at their girdles, as coming from church. They meet.

sp.speaker: Nich.
sp.p: What corporal oath? I am sorry we have met with you next our hearts; you are the man that we are forbidden to keep company withal, we must not swear I can tell you, and you have the name for swearing.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p: Ay, corporal oath, I would you would do so much as forsake us sir, we cannot abide you, we must not be seen in your company.

sp.speaker: F●ail.
sp.p: There is none of us I can tell you, but shall be soundly whipped for swearing.

sp.speaker: Corporal
sp.p: Why how now? we three? Puritanical scrape-shoes, flesh a good Fridayes? A hand.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: Oh.

sp.speaker: Corporal
sp.p: Why Nicholas Saint-tantlings, Simon saint Mary oueries, has the devil possessed you, that you swear no better, you half-christened katamites, you ungod-mothered varlets, does the first lesson teach you to be proud, and the second to be coxcombs; proud coxcombs? not once to do duty to a man of mark.

sp.speaker: Frail.
sp.p: A man of mark, quatha, I do not think he can show a beggar's noble.

sp.speaker: Corpe.
sp.p: A corporal, a commander, one of spirit; that is able to blow you up all dry with your books at your girdles.

sp.speaker: Simon.
sp.p: We are not taught to believe that sir, for we know the breath of man is weak?

sp.speaker: Frail.
sp.p: Foh, you lie Nicholas; for here's one strong enough; blow us up quatha, he may well blow me above twelvescore off an him? I warrant if the wind stood right, a man might smell him from the top of Newgate, to the leads of Ludgate?

sp.speaker: Corporal
sp.p: Sirrah, thou hollow-book of wax-candle.

sp.speaker: Nicho.
sp.p: Ay, you may say what you will, so you swear not.

sp.speaker: Corporal
sp.p: I swear by the —

sp.speaker: Nicho.
sp.p: Hold, hold, good corporal oath; for if you swear once, we shall all fall down in a swoon presently.

sp.speaker: Corporal
sp.p: I must and will swear: you quivering coxcombs, my captain is imprisoned, and by Uulcan's leather codpiece point —

sp.speaker: Nich.
sp.p: O Simon, what an oath was there.

sp.speaker: Frail.
sp.p: If he should chance to break it, the poor man's breeches would fall down about his heels, for Venus allows him but one point to his hose?

sp.speaker: Corporal
sp.p: With these my bully-feet, I will thump open the prison doors, and brain the keeper with the begging box, but I'll set my honest sweet captain idle at liberty.

sp.speaker: Nich.
sp.p: How, captain idle, my old aunt's son, my dear kinsman in Capadochio.

sp.speaker: Corporal
sp.p: Ay, thou church-peeling, thou holy-pa●ing, religious outside thou? if thou hadst any grace in thee, thou wouldst visit him, relieve him, swear to get him out?

sp.speaker: Nich●.
sp.p: Assure you corporal indeed-la, 'tis the first time I heard on't,

sp.speaker: Corporal
sp.p: Why do 't now then, marmoset? bring forth thy yearly-wages, let not a commander perish!

sp.speaker: Simon.
sp.p: But, if he be one of the wicked, he shall perish.

sp.speaker: Nich.
sp.p: Well corporal, I'll e'en along with you, to visit my kinsman, if I can do him any good, I will, — but I have nothing for him, Simon saint Mary oueris and frailty, pray make a lie for me to the knight my master, old sir Godfrey.

sp.speaker: Corporal
sp.p: A lie? may you lie then?

sp.speaker: Fray.
sp.p: O ay, we may lie, but me must not swear.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p: True, we may lie with our neighbour's wife, but we must not swear we did so;

sp.speaker: Corporal
sp.p: O, an excellent tag of religion?

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: O Simon, I have thought upon a sound excuse, it will go currant, say that I am gone to a fast;

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p: To a fast, very good?

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: Ay, to a fast say, with master full-belly the minister.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p: Master full-belly? an honest man: he feeds the flock well, for he's an excellent feeder?

sp.speaker: Fray.
sp.p: O ay, I have seen him eat up a whole pig, and afterwards falls to the pettitoes?

div.stage: Enter captain ydle at one door, and old soldier at the other.

sp.speaker: Pye.
sp.p: Pray turn the key.

sp.speaker: Sker.
sp.p: Turn the key I pray?

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: Who should those be, I almost know their voices? O my friends?
You're welcome to a smelling room here? you newly took leave of the air is't not a strange savour?

sp.speaker: Pie.
sp.l: 'As all prisons have, smells of sundry wretcher;
Who though departed, leave their scents behind 'em,
By gold captain, I am sincerely sorry for thee.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: By my troth George I thank thee; but pish, — what must be, must be.

sp.speaker: Skir.
sp.p: Captain, what do you lie in for? is't great? what's your offence?

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: Faith, my offence is ordinary, — common? A highway, and I fear me my penalty will be ordinary and common too, a halter.

sp.speaker: Pie.
sp.l: Nay prophecy not so ill, it shall go herd '
But I'll shift for thy life.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: Whether I live or die, thou art an honest George I'll tell you — silver stoved not with me, as it had done, (For now the tide runs to bawds and flatterers) I had a start out, and by chance set upon a fat steward, thinking his purse had been as pursy as his body; and the slave had about him but the poor purchase of ten groats: notwithstanding being descried, pursued, and taken, I know the law is so grim: in respect of many desperate-unsettled soldiers, that I fear me I shall dance after their pipe for't.

sp.speaker: Skir.
sp.p: I am twice sorry for you captain: first that your purchase was so small, and now that your danger is so great.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: Push, the worst is but death, — ha you a pipe of tobacco about you?

sp.speaker: Skir.
sp.p: I think, I have thereabouts about me!

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: Here's a clean gentleman too, to receive?

sp.speaker: Pie.
sp.l: Well, I must cast about, some happy slight,
Work brain, that ever didst thy master right?

sp.speaker: Corporal
sp.p: Keeper? let the key be turned

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: Ay, I pray master keeper gives a cast of your office?Within.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: How now ● more visitants? — what corporal oath?

sp.speaker: Pie. Skir.
sp.p: Corporal?

sp.speaker: Corporal
sp.p: In prison honest captain? this must not be?

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: How do you captain kinsman?

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: Good coxcomb? what makes that pure — starched fool here?

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: You see kinsman I am somewhat bold to call in, and see how you do, I heard you were safe enough, and I was very glad on't that it was no worse;

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.l: This is a double torture now, — this fool by'th book
Does vex me more than my imprisonment?
What meant you corporal to hook him hither?

sp.speaker: Corporal
sp.l: Who he? he shall relieve thee, and supply thee,
I'll make him do't;

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: Fie, what vain breath you spend! he supply? I'll sooner expect mercy from a usurer when my bonds forfeited, sooner kindness from a lawyer when my money's spent: nay sooner charity from the devil, then good from a Puritan? I'll look for relief from him, when Lucifer is restored to his blood, and in heaven again!

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: I warrant my kinsman's talking of me, for my left ear burns most tyrannically?

sp.speaker: Pie.
sp.p: Captain idle? what's he there? he look; like a monkey upward; and a crane downward.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: Pshaw; a foolish cousin of nine; I must thank God for him.

sp.speaker: Pie.
sp.p: Why the better subject to work a scape upon; thou shalt e'en change clothes with him, and leave him here, and so;

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: Push, I published him e'en now to my corporal, he will be damned, ere he do me so much good; why I know a more proper, a more handsome device then that, if the slave would be sociable — now goodman fleer-face?

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: O, my cousin begins to speak to me now, I shall be acquainted with him again I hope,

sp.speaker: Skirmish.
sp.p: Look what ridiculous raptures take hold of his wrinkles,

sp.speaker: Pye.
sp.p: Then what say you to this device, a happy one captain?

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: Speak low George; prison rats have wider ears than those in malt-lofts.

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: Cousin, if it lay in my power, as they say? — to — do;

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: 'Twould do me an exceeding pleasure indeed that, but ● ere talk further on't, the fool will be hanged, ere he do't.

sp.speaker: Corporal
sp.p: Pax, I'll thump 'em to't.

sp.speaker: Pie.
sp.p: Why do but try the fopster, and break it to him bluntly.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: And so my disgrace will dwell in his jaws, and the slave slaver out our purpose to his master, for would I were but as sure on't as I am sure he will deny to do't.

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: I would be heartily glad cousin, if any of my friendships, as they say, might — stand, ah,

sp.speaker: Pie.
sp.p: Why, you see he offers his friendship foolishly to you already?

sp.speaker: Captain.
sp.p: Ay, that's the 〈◊〉 on't, I would he would offer it wisely?

sp.speaker: Nich.
sp.p: Verily, and indeed la, cousin? —

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: I have taken note of thy steers a good while, if thou art minded to do me good? as thou gap'st upon me comfortably, and givest me charitable faces? which indeed is but a fashion in you all that are Puritaines? wilt soon at night steal me thy master's chain?

sp.speaker: Nich.
sp.p: O, I shall swoon!

sp.speaker: Pie.
sp.p: Corporal, he starts already!

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: I know it to be worth three hundred crowns, and with the half of that, I can buy my life at a broker's, at second hand, which now lies in pawn to'th law, if this thou refuse to do, being easy and nothing dangerous, in that thou art held in good opinion of thy master, why 'tis a palpable argument thou holdest my life at no price, and these thy broken and unjointed offers, are but only created in thy lip, now born, and now buried, foolish breath only? what; wilt do't? shall I look for happiness in thy answer?

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: Steal my master's chain quo 'Thee? no, it shall ne'er be said that Nicholas saint Tantlings committed birdlime!

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: Nay, I told you as much; did I not; though he be a Puritan yet he will be a true man?

sp.speaker: Nich.
sp.p: Why cousin? you know 'tis written, thou shalt not steal?

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: Why, and fool, thou shalt love thy neighbour, and help him in extremities?

sp.speaker: Nich.
sp.p: Mass I think it be indeed, in what chapter's that cousin?

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: Why in the first of charity, the 2. verse.

sp.speaker: Nich.
sp.p: The first of charity, qua than, that's a good jest, there's no such chapter in my book!

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: No, I knew 'twas torn out of thy book, and that makes so little in thy heart.

sp.speaker: Pie.
sp.p: Come, let me tell you, you're too unkind a kinsman i'faith; the captain loving you so dear, ay, like the Pomwater of his eye, and you to be so uncomfortable, fie, fie.

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: Pray do not wish me to be hanged, any thing else that I can do, had it been to rob, I would ha' don't, but I must not steal, that's the word the literal, thou shalt not steal, and would you wish me to steal then?

sp.speaker: Pie.
sp.p: No faith, that were to much, to speak truth: why wilt thou nim it from him.

sp.speaker: Nich.
sp.p: That I will?

sp.speaker: Pie.
sp.p: Why enough bully; he shall be content with that, or he shall ha' none; let me alone with him now! Captain, I ha' dealt with your kinsman in a corner; a good — kind — natured fellow, methinks : go too, you shall not have all your own asking, you shall bate somewhat on't he is not contented absolutely as you would say to steal the chain from him, — but to do you a pleasure he will nim it from him.

sp.speaker: Nich.
sp.p: Ay, that I will, cousin.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: Well seeing he will do no more, as far as I see I must be contented with that.

sp.speaker: Corporal
sp.p: Here's no notable gullery?

sp.speaker: Pie.
sp.p: Nay I'll come nearer to you gentleman? because we'll have only but a help and a mirth on't, the knight shall not lose his chain neither, but be only laid out of the way some one or two days?

sp.speaker: Nich.
sp.p: Ay, that would be good indeed? Kinsman?

sp.speaker: Pie.
sp.p:
For I have a farther reach to profit us better by the missing on't only, then if we had it outright, as my discourse shall make it known too you? — when thou hast the chain, do but
convey it out at backdoor into the garden, and there hang it close in the rosemary bank, but for a small season; and by that harmless device, I know how to wind captain idle, out of prison, the knight thy master shall get his pardon and release him, and he satisfy thy master with his own chain and wondrous thanks on both hands.

sp.speaker: Nich.
sp.p: That were rare indeed la●pray let me know how?

sp.speaker: Pie.
sp.p: Nay 'tis very necessary thou shouldst know, because thou must be employed as an actor?

sp.speaker: Nich.
sp.p: An actor? O no, that's a player? and our parson rails again players mightily I can tell you, because they brought him drunk upo'th' stage once, — as he will be horribly drunk.

sp.speaker: Corporal
sp.p: Mass I cannot blame him then, poor church-spout?

sp.speaker: Pie.
sp.p: Why as an intermeddler then?

sp.speaker: Nich.
sp.p: I that, that.

sp.speaker: Pie.
sp.p: Give me audience then? when the old knight thy master has raged his fill for the loss of the chain, tell him thou hast a kinsman in prison, of such exquisite art, that the devil himself is French lackey to him, and runs bareheaded by his horse — belly (When he has one) whom he will cause with most Irish dexterity to fetch his chain, though 'twere hid under a mine of seacoal, and ne'er make spade or pickaxe his instruments, tell him but this with farther instructions thou shalt receive from me, and thou showst thyself a kinsman indeed.

sp.speaker: Corporal
sp.p: A dainty bully.

sp.speaker: Skir.
sp.p: An honest — book keeper.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: And my three times thrice honey cousin.

sp.speaker: ●nich.
sp.p: Nay grace of God I'll rob him on't suddenly? and hang it in the rosemary bank, but I bear that mind cousin I would not steal any thing methinks for mine own father.

sp.speaker: Skir.
sp.p: He bears a good mind in that captain!

sp.speaker: Pie.
sp.p: Why well said, he begins to be an honest fellow faith.

sp.speaker: Corporal
sp.p: In troth he does.

sp.speaker: Nich.
sp.p: You see cousin, I am willing to do you any kindness, always saving myself harmless?

sp.speaker: Captain.
sp.p: Why I thank thee, fare thee well, I shall requite it.

sp.speaker: Corporal
sp.p: 'Twill be good for thee captain, that thou hast such an egregious ass to thy cousin.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.l: Ay, is he not a fine fool corporal?
But George thou talkest of art and conjuring,
How shall that be?

sp.speaker: Peb.
sp.l: Puh, be't not in your care,
Leave that to me and my directions;
Well captain doubt not thy delivery now,
E 'En with the vantage man, to gain by prison,
As my thoughts prompt me: hold on brain and plot,
I aim at many cunning far events,
All which I doubt not but to hit at length,
I'll to the widow with a quaint assault,
Captain be merry.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: Who I? Kerrie merry buff-jerkin?

sp.speaker: Pye.
sp.p: O, I am happy in more slights, and one will knit strong in another — corporal oath?

sp.speaker: Corporal
sp.p: Hoh bully?

sp.speaker: Pye.
sp.p: And thou old Peter skirmish, I have a necessary task for you both.

sp.speaker: Skir.
sp.p: Lay't upon George Pie-board.

sp.speaker: Corporal
sp.p: whate'er it be, we'll manage it.

sp.speaker: Pye.
sp.l: I would have you two maintain a quarrel before the
Lady widow's door, and draw your swords i'th edge of the
Evening: clash a little, clash, clash.

sp.speaker: Corporal
sp.l: Fuh.
Let us alone to make our blades ring noon,
Though it be after supper.

sp.speaker: Pye.
sp.l: Know you can;
sp.p:
And out of that false fire, I doubt not but to raise strange belief — and captain to countenance my device the better, and grace my words to the widow, I have a good plain satin suit, that I had of a young reveller tother night, for words pass not regarded nowadays unless they come from a good suit of clothes, which the fates and my wits have bestowed upon me. Well captain idle, if I did not highly love thee, I would
ne'er be seen within twelve score of a prison, for I protest at this instant, I walk in great danger of small debts . owe I money to several hostesses, and you know such lill● 〈…〉 be upon a man's jack.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: True George?

sp.speaker: Pye.
sp.p: Fare thee well captain. Come corporal and ancient? thou shalt hear more news next time we greet thee?

sp.speaker: Corporal
sp.p: More news? I; by you bear at bridge-foot in heaven shalt thou.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.l: Enough: my friend's farewell,
This prison shows as if ghosts did part in hell.

div.stage: Enter Moll youngest daughter to the widow: alone.

sp.speaker: Moll.
sp.p: Not marry: forswear marriage? why all women know 'tis as honourable a thing as to lie with a man; and I to spite my sisters vow the more, have entertained a suitor already ▪ a fine gallant knight of the last feather, he says he will coach me too, and well appoint me, allow me money to dice withal, and many such pleasing protestations he sticks upon my lips; indeed his short-winded father ith' country is wondrous wealthy, a most abominable farmer, and therefore he may do't in time: troth I'll venture upon him; women are not without ways enough to help themselves ▪ if he prove wise and good as his word, why I shall love him, and use him kindly: and if he prove an ass, why in a quarter of an hour's warning I can transform him into an ox; — there comes in my relief again.

sp.speaker: Frail.
sp.p: O mistress Moll, mistress Moll.

sp.speaker: Moll.
sp.p: How now? what's the news?

sp.speaker: Frail.
sp.p: The knight your suitor, sir John Pennydub.

sp.speaker: Moll.
sp.p: Sir John Pennydub? where? where?

sp.speaker: Frail.
sp.p: He's walking in the gallery.

sp.speaker: Moll.
sp.p: Has my mother seen him yet.

sp.speaker: Frail.
sp.p: O no, she's — spitting in the kitchen.

sp.speaker: Moll.
sp.p: Direct him hither softly, good frailty, — I'll meet him half way.

sp.speaker: Frail.
sp.p: That's just like running a tilt; but I hope he'll break nothing this time.

sp.speaker: Moll.
sp.l: 'Tis happiness my mother saw him not:
Oh we come good sir John.

sp.speaker: Pennydub.
sp.p: I thank you faith, — nay you must stand me, till I kiss you: 'tis the fashion everywhere i'faith, and I came from court enough?

sp.speaker: Moll.
sp.p: Nay the fates forfend that I should anger the fashion?

sp.speaker: Penny.
sp.p: Then not forgetting the sweet of new ceremonies, I first fall back, then recovering myself; make my honour to your lip thus: and then accost it.

sp.speaker: Moll.
sp.l: Trust me, very pretty, and moving, you're worthy on't sir, —
Oh my mother, my mother, now she's here,
sp.stage: Kissing: ent. Widow and sir godfr.
sp.l: We'll steal into the gallery.

sp.speaker: Sir Godf.
sp.p: Nay sister, let reason rule you, do not play the fool, stand not in your own light, you have wealthy offers, large tendrings, do not withstand your good fortune: who comes a-wooing to you I pray? no small fool, a rich knight ath' city, sir Oliver muckhill, no small fool I can tell you: and furthermore as I heard late by your maidservants, (As your maidservants will say to me any thing I thank 'em) both your daughters are not without suitors, ay, and worthy ones too? one a brisk courtier, sir Andrew tipstaff; suitor afar off to your eldest daughter, and the third a huge-wealthy farmer's son, a fine young country knight, they call him sir John Penny-dab, a good name marry, he may have it coined when he lacks money: what blessings are these sister?

sp.speaker: Widow
sp.p: Tempt me not Satan.

sp.speaker: Sir Godf.
sp.p: Satan? do I look like Satan? I hope the devil's not so old as I, I trow.

sp.speaker: Widow
sp.l: You wound my sense's brother, when you name,
A suitor to me, — o I cannot abide it,
I take in poison, when I hear one named,
How now Simon? where's my son Edmund?

sp.speaker: Sim,
sp.p: Verily madam, he is at vain exercise, dripping in he tennis-court.

sp.speaker: Widow
sp.p: At tennis-court? o, now his father's gone, I shall have no rule with him; o wicked Edmond, I might well compare this with the prophecy in the chronicle, though fart inferior, as Harry of Monmouth won all, and harry of Windsor lost all, so Edmund of Brist●● that was the father, got all, and Edmond of London that's his son now, will spend all?

sp.speaker: Sir Godf.
sp.p: Peace sister, we'll have hem reformed, there's hope on him yet, though it be but a little.

sp.speaker: Frail.
sp.p: Forsooth madam? there are two or three archers at door, would very gladly speak with your ladyship.

sp.speaker: Widow
sp.p: Archers?

sp.speaker: Sir Godf.
sp.p: Your husband's Fletcher I warrant.

sp.speaker: Widow
sp.l: O,
Let them come near, they bring home things of his,
Troth I should ha' forgotten 'em, how now?
Villain, which be those archers?

div.stage: Enter the suitors sir Andrew Tipstaff, sir Oliver Much-hill, and Pennydub.

sp.speaker: Frail.
sp.p: Who do you not see 'em before you, are not these archers, what do you call 'em Shooter's: Shooter's and archers are all one I hope.

sp.speaker: Widow
sp.p: Out ignorant slave.

sp.speaker: Muck
sp.l: Nay pray be patient lady,
We come in way of honourable love.

sp.speaker: Tipstaff Penny.
sp.p: We do.

sp.speaker: Muck.
sp.p: To you.

sp.speaker: Tipstaff Penny.
sp.p: And to your daughters?

sp.speaker: Widow.
sp.p:
O why will you offer me this gentlemen? indeed I will not look upon you; when the tears are scarce out of mine eyes, not yet washed off from my cheeks, and my dear husband's body scarse so cold as the coffin, what reason have you to offer it? I am not like some of your widows that will bury one in the evening, and be sure to another ere morning? pray away, pray, take your answers good
knights, and you be sweet knights, I have vowed never to marry; — and so have my daughters too!

sp.speaker: Penny.
sp.p: I two of you have, but the thirds a good wench!

sp.speaker: Muck.
sp.p: Lady, a shrewd answer many; the best is, 'tis but the first, and he's a blunt wooer, that will leave for one sharp answer.

sp.speaker: Tipstaff
sp.p: Where be your daughter's lady, I hope they'll give us better encouragements?

sp.speaker: Widow
sp.p: Indeed they'll answer you so, take't a my word they'll give you the very same answer verbatim cruelly la;

sp.speaker: Penny
sp.p: Mum: molls a good wench still, I know what she'll do?

sp.speaker: Muck.
sp.p: Well, lady, for this time we'll take our leaves, hoping for better comfort.

sp.speaker: Widow
sp.p: O never, never? and I live these thousand years; and you be good knights do not hope; 'twill be all vain, vain, — look you, put off all yours suits, and you come to me again.

sp.speaker: Fray.
sp.p: Put off all their suits qua than? Ay, that's the best wooing of a widow indeed, when a man's nonsuited, that is, when he's a-bed with her.

div.stage: Going out, Muckhill and sir Godfrey.

sp.speaker: Muck.
sp.p: Sir Godfrey? here's twenty angels more work hard for me; there's life in't yet.

sp.speaker: Sir Godf.
sp.p: Fear not sir Oliver muckhill, I'll stick close for you, leave all with me.

sp.speaker: Pye.
sp.p: By your leave lady widow.

sp.speaker: Widow
sp.p: What another suitor now?

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.l: A suitor no I protest lady? if you'd give me yourself
I'd not be troubled with you.

sp.speaker: Widow
sp.p: Say you so sir, then you're the better welcome sir.

sp.speaker: Pie.
sp.p: Nay heaven bless me from a widow, unless I were sure to bury her speedily!

sp.speaker: Widow
sp.p: Good bluntness: well your business sit?

sp.speaker: Pie.
sp.p: Very needful; if you were in private once?

sp.speaker: Widow
sp.p: Needful? brother pray leave us; and you sit?

sp.speaker: Fray.
sp.p:
I should laugh now, if this blunt fellow should put 'em
all by side the stirrup, and vault into the saddle himself, I have seen as mad a trick.

sp.speaker: Widow
sp.p: Now sir? — here's none but we — daughters forbear.

sp.speaker: Pyb.
sp.p: O no, pray let 'em stay, for what I have to speak importeth equally to them as to you?

sp.speaker: Widow
sp.p: Then you may stay.

sp.speaker: Pyb.
sp.l: I pray bestow on me a serious ear,
For what I speak is full of weight and fear?

sp.speaker: Widow
sp.p: Fear?

sp.speaker: Pyb.
sp.l: I if't pass unregarded, and uneffected,
Else peace and joy: — I pray attention?
sp.p: Widow? I have been a mere stranger for these parts that you live in, nor did I ever know the husband of you, and father of them, but I truly know by certain spiritual intelligence, that he is in purgatory?

sp.speaker: Widow
sp.p: Purgatory? tuh; that word deserves to be spit upon; I wonder that a man of sober tongue as you seem to be, should have the folly to believe there's such a place.

sp.speaker: Pyb.
sp.p: Well lady, in cold blood I speak it, I assure you that there is a purgatory, in which place I know your husband to reside and wherein he is like to remain, till the dissolution of the world, till the last general bonfire: when all the earth shall melt into nothing. And the seas scaled their finny labourers: so long is his abidance, unless you alter the property of your purpose, together with each of your daughters theirs, that is, the purpose of single life in yourself and your eldest daughter, and the speedy determination of marriage in your youngest.

sp.speaker: Moll.
sp.p: How knows he that, what, has some devil told him?

sp.speaker: Widow
sp.l: Strange he should know our thoughts: —
Why but daughter have you purposed speedy marriage?

sp.speaker: Pyb.
sp.p: You see she tells you ay, for she says nothing. Nay give me credit as you please, I am a stranger to you, and and yet you see I know your determinations, which must come to me metaphysically, and by a supernatural intelligence.

sp.speaker: Vvid.
sp.p: This puts amazement on me?

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: Know our seacrets.

sp.speaker: Mol.
sp.l: I'd thought to steal a marriage, would his tongue
Had dropped out when he blabbed it.

sp.speaker: Vvid.
sp.p: But sir, my husband, was too honest a dealing man to be now in any purgatories —

sp.speaker: Pie.
sp.l: O do not load your conscience with untruths,
'Tis but mere folly now to guild hem o'er:
That has passed but for copper; praises here,
Cannot unbind him there? confess but truth,
I know he got his wealth with a hard gripe:
O hardly, hardly?

sp.speaker: Widow
sp.p: This is most strange of all, how knows he that?

sp.speaker: Pie.
sp.l: He would eat fools and ignorant heirs clean up;
And had his drink, from many a poor man's brow,
E'en as their labour brewed it?
He would scrape riches to him most unjustly;
The very dirt between his nails was ill-got:
And not his own, — o
sp.p: I groan to speak on't, the though't makes me shudder? — shudder?

sp.speaker: Vvid.
sp.p: It quakes me too, now I think on't — sir, I am much grieved, that you a stranger should so deeply wrong my dead husband!

sp.speaker: Pi●.
sp.p: O?

sp.speaker: Vvid.
sp.p: A man that would keep church so duly; rise early, before his servants, and e'en for religious haste, go ungartered, unbuttoned, nay sir reverence untrust, to morning prayer?

sp.speaker: Pi●.
sp.p: O uff;

sp.speaker: Vvid.
sp.p: Dine quickly upon high-days, and when I had great guess, would e'en shame me and rise from the table, to get a good seat at an afternoon sermon?

sp.speaker: Pie.
sp.p: There's the devil, there's the devil, true, he thought it sanctity enough, if he had killed a man, so● 'thad been done in a Pew, or undone his neighbour, so ta'd been near enough to'th preacher, o; — a sermon's a fine short cloak of an hour long, and will hide the upper-part of a dissembler, — church, ay, he beseemed all church, and his conscience was as hard as the pulpit!

sp.speaker: Vvid.
sp.p: I can no more endure this.

sp.speaker: Pie,
sp.l: Nor I widow
Endure to flatter.

sp.speaker: Widow
sp.p: Is this all your business with me?

sp.speaker: Pie,
sp.l: No, lady, 'tis but the induction to't,
You may believe my strains, I strike all true?
sp.p: And if your conscience would leap up to your tongue, yourself would affirm it, and that you shall perceive I know of things to come; as well as I do of what is present, a brother of your husbands shall shortly have a loss!

sp.speaker: Widow
sp.p: A loss, marry heaven forfend, sir Godfrey, my brother!

sp.speaker: Pie.
sp.p: Nay keep in your wonders, till I have told you the fortunes of you all; which are more fearful, if not happily prevented — for your part and your daughters, if there be not once this day some bloodshed before your door, whereof the human creature dies? two of you the elder shall run mad?

sp.speaker: Mother and Frank.
sp.p: Oh.

sp.speaker: Mol.
sp.p: That's not I yet!

sp.speaker: Pie.
sp.p: And with most impudent prostitution show your naked bodies to the view of all beholders!

sp.speaker: Widow
sp.p: Our naked bodies? fie for shame:

sp.speaker: Pie.
sp.p: Attend me: and your younger daughter be strucken dumb?

sp.speaker: Mol.
sp.p: Dumb? out alas: 'tis the worst pain of all for a woman, I'd rather be mad, or run naked, or any thing: dumb?

sp.speaker: Pie.
sp.p: Give ear? ere the evening fall upon, hill bog, and meadow, this my speech shall have past probation, and then shall I be believed accordingly.

sp.speaker: Widow.
sp.p: If this be true, we are all shamed, all undone?

sp.speaker: Mol.
sp.p: Dumb? I'll speak as much as ever I can possible before evening?

sp.speaker: Pie.
sp.p:
But if it so come to pass (As for your fair sakes I wish it may) that this presage of your strange fortunes be prevented by that accident of death and bloodshedding which I before told you off: take heed upon your lives; that two of you which have vowed never to marry, seek you out husbands with all present speed
and you the third that have such a desire to outstrip chastity, look you meddle not with a husband.

sp.speaker: Moll.
sp.p: A double torment.

sp.speaker: Pyb.
sp.p: The breach of this keeps your father in purgatory, and the punishments that shall follow you in this world, would with horror kill the ear should hear 'em related.

sp.speaker: Widow
sp.p: Marry? why I vowed never to marry.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: And so did I.

sp.speaker: Moll.
sp.p: And I vowed never to be such an ass, but to marry. what a cross fortune's this?

sp.speaker: Pyb.
sp.p: Ladies, though I be a fortune-teller, I cannot better fortunes, you have 'em from me as they are revealed to me: I would they were to your tempers, and fellows with your bloods, that's all the bitterness I would you.

sp.speaker: Widow.
sp.p: O 'tis a just vengeance, for my husband's hard purchases.

sp.speaker: Pyb.
sp.p: I wish you to bethink yourselves, and leavem.

sp.speaker: Widow
sp.p: I'll to sir Godfrey my brother, and acquaint him with these fearful presages.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: For mother they portend losses to him.

sp.speaker: Widow
sp.l: O ay, they do, they do,
If any happy issue crown thy words,
I will reward thy cunning.

sp.speaker: Pyb.
sp.l: 'Tis enough lady,
I wish no higher.

sp.speaker: Mol.
sp.l: Dumb, and not marry, worse,
Neither to speak, nor kiss, a double curse?

sp.speaker: Pyb.
sp.p:
So all this comes well about yet, I play the fortune-teller, as well as if I had had a witch to my grannam: for by good happiness, being in my hostesses garden, which neighbours the orchard of the widow, I laid the hole of mine ear to a hole in the wall, and heard 'em make these vows, and speak those words upon which I wrought these advantages; and to encourage my forgery the more, I may now perceive in 'em a natural simplicity which will easily swallow an abuse, if any covering be over it: and to confirm my former presage to the widow, I have advised old Peter skirmish the soldier, to hurt corporal oath upon the leg, and in that hurry I'll rush amongst
'em, and in stead of giving the corporal some cordial to comfort him, I'll power into his mouth a potion of a sleepy nature, to make him seem as dead; for the which the old soldier being apprehended, and ready to be born to execution, I'll step in, and take upon me the cure of the dead man, upon pain of dying the condemned's death: the corporal will wake at his minute, when the sleepy force has wrought itself, and so shall I get myself into a most admired opinion, and under the pretext of that cunning, beguile as I see occasion: and if that foolish Nicholas saint Tantlings keep true time with the chain, my plot will be found; the captain delivered, and my wits applauded among scholars and soldiers for ever.

div.stage: Enter Nicholas saint Tantlings with the chain.

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: O I have found an excellent advantage to take a way the chain, my master put it off e'en now to say on a new doublet, and I sneaked it away by little and little most puritanically! we shall have good sport anon when has missed it, about my cousin the conjurer ▪ the world shall see I'm an honest man of my word for now I'm going to hang it between heaven and earth among the rosemary branches.

div.head: Actus 3.

sp.speaker: Frai.
sp.p: Sirrah Simon saint? my mistress sends away all her suitors and puts fleas 〈◊〉 ears?

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p: Frailty? she dos like an honest chaste, and virtuous woman? for widows ought not to wallow in the puddle of iniquity.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.p: Yet Simon, many widows will do't, what so comes on't.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p: True frailty, their filthy flesh desires a conjunction copulative what strangers are within, frailty?

sp.speaker: Fra●.
sp.p: There's none Simon but master Pilfer the tailor: he's above with sir Godfrey praising of a doublet: and I must trudge anon to fetch master suds the barber!

sp.speaker: Simon.
sp.l: Master suds, a good man, he washes the sins of the
Beard clean.

sp.speaker: Skir
sp.p: How now creatures? what's o'clock .

sp.speaker: Frai.
sp.p: Why do you take us to be jack a'th' clockhouse?

sp.speaker: Skir.
sp.p: I say again to you what's o'clock ?

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p: Truly la, we go by the clock of our conscience, all worldly clocks we know go false, and are set by drunken sextons.

sp.speaker: Skir.
sp.p: Then what's o'clock in your conscience? — o, I must break off, here comes the corporal — hum, hum! — what's o'clock ?

sp.speaker: Corporal
sp.p: o'clock ? why passed seventeen.

sp.speaker: Frai.
sp.p: Past seventeen? nay has met with his match now, corporal oath will fit him.

sp.speaker: Skir.
sp.p: Thou dost not balk or baffle me, dost thou▪ I am a soldier — past seventeen.

sp.speaker: Corporal
sp.p: Ay, thou art not angry with the figures art thou? I will prove it unto thee, 12. and 1. is thirteen I hope, 2. fourteen, 3. fifteen, 4 sixteen, and 5. seventeen, then passed seventeen, I will take the dial's part in a just cause.

sp.speaker: Skir.
sp.p: I say 'tis but passed five then.

sp.speaker: Corporal
sp.p: I'll swear 'tis past seventeen then▪ dost thou not know numbers, canst thou not cast?

sp.speaker: Skir.
sp.p: Cast? dost thou speak of my casting ith' street? Draw.

sp.speaker: Corporal
sp.p: Ay, and in the market place.

sp.speaker: Sim,
sp.p: Clubs, clubs, clubs.

sp.speaker: Frail.
sp.p: Ay, I known by their shuffling clubs would be trump; mass here's the knave, and he can do any good upon 'em: clubs, clubs, clubs?

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: O villain, thou hast opened a vain in my leg.

sp.speaker: Pyb.
sp.p: How now, for shame, for shame, put up, put up.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: By yond blue welkin, 'twas out of my part George to be hurt on the leg.

sp.speaker: Pyb.
sp.p: O peace now — I have a cordial here to comfort thee.

sp.speaker: Officer
sp.p: Down with 'em, down with 'em, lay hands upon the villain.

sp.speaker: Skir.
sp.p: Lay hands on me?.

sp.speaker: Pyb.
sp.p: I'll not be seen among 'em now.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.l: I'm hurt, and had more need have surgeons,
Lay hands upon me then rough officers.

sp.speaker: Officer
sp.l: Go carry him to be dressed then:
This mutinous soldier shall along with me to prison.

sp.speaker: Skir.
sp.p: To prison, where's George.

sp.speaker: Officer
sp.p: Away with hem.

sp.speaker: Pyb.
sp.l: So ▪
All lights as I would wish, the amazed widow,
Will plant me strongly now in her belief,
And wonder at the virtue of my words:
For the event turns those presages from 'em
Of being mad and dumb, and begets joy
Mingled with admiration: these empty creatures,
Soldier and corporal were but ordained,
As instruments for me to work upon,
Now to my patient, here's his potion.

div.stage: Enter the widow with her two daughters.

sp.speaker: Widow
sp.l: O wondrous happiness, beyond our thoughts:
Oh lucky fair event, I think our fortunes,
Were blessed e'en in our cradles: we are quit
Of all those shameful violent presages,
By this rash bleeding chance; go frailty run, and know,
Whether he be yet living ▪ or yet dead,
That here before my door received his hurt.

sp.speaker: Frail.
sp.p: Madam, he was carried to the superior, but if he had no money when he came there, I warrant he's dead by this time.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: Sure that man is a rare fortune-teller, never looked upon our hands, nor upon any mark about us, a wondrous fellow surely.

sp.speaker: Moll.
sp.p: I am glad, I have the use of my tongue yet: though of nothing else, I shall find the way to marry too, I hope shortly.

sp.speaker: Widow
sp.p: O where's my brother sir Godfrey, I would he were here, that I might relate to him how prophetically, the cunning gentleman spoke in all things.

div.stage: Enter sir Godfrey in a rage.

sp.speaker: Sir Godf.
sp.p: O my chain, my chain, I have lost my chain, where be these villains, varlets?

sp.speaker: Vvid.
sp.p: O; has lost his chain.

sp.speaker: Sir Godf.
sp.p: My chain, my chain.

sp.speaker: Widow.
sp.p:
Brother be patient, hear me speak, you know
I told you that a cunning man told me, that you should have a loss, and he has prophesied so true.

sp.speaker: Sir Godf.
sp.p: Out he's a villain, to prophecy of the loss of my chain, 'twas worth above three hundred crowns, — besides 'twas my fathers, my father's fathers, my grandfathers huge grandfathers? I had as live ha' lost my neck, as the chain that hung about it; oh my chain, my chain.

sp.speaker: Widow
sp.p: O brother, who can be against a misfortune, 'tis happy 'twas no more.

sp.speaker: Sir Godf.
sp.p: No, more! O goodly godly sister, would you had me lost more? my best gown too, with the cloth of goldlace? my holiday Gascoines, and my jerkin set with pearl; no more?

sp.speaker: Widow
sp.p: O, brother! you can read. —

sp.speaker: Sir Godf.
sp.p: But I cannot read where my chain is, — what strangers have been here? you let in strangers! The eves, and catchpoles; how comes it gone? there was none above with me but my tailor; and my tailor will not — steal I hope?

sp.speaker: Mol.
sp.p: No he's afraid of a chain!

sp.speaker: Widow
sp.p: How now sirrah, the news?

sp.speaker: Fray.
sp.p: O mistress, he may well be called a corporal now, for his corpses are as dead as a cold capons?

sp.speaker: Widow
sp.p: More happiness.

sp.speaker: Sir Godf.
sp.p: Sirrah, what's this to my chain? where's my chain knave?

sp.speaker: Fray.
sp.p: Your chain sir?

sp.speaker: Sir Godf.
sp.p: My chain is lost villain.

sp.speaker: Fray.
sp.p: I would he were hanged in chains that has it then for me? Alas sir, I saw none of your chain, since you were hung with it yourself?

sp.speaker: Sir Godf.
sp.l: Out varlet? it had full three thousand links,
I have oft told it over at my prayers:
Over and over, full three thousand links.

sp.speaker: Frayl.
sp.p: Had it so sir: sure it cannot be lost then; I'll put you in that comfort.

sp.speaker: Sir Godf.
sp.p: Why why?

sp.speaker: Frayl.
sp.p:
Why if your chain had so many links, it cannot
choose but come to light.

sp.speaker: Sir Godf.
sp.p: Delusion? now long Nicholas where's my chain.

sp.speaker: Nich.
sp.p: Why about your neck, is't not sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Godf.
sp.l: About my neck varlet. My chain is lost,
'Tis stole away, I'm robbed.

sp.speaker: Widow
sp.p: Nay brother show yourself a man:

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: I if it be lost or stole, if he would be patient mistress I could bring him to a cunning kinsman of mine that would fetched again with a sesar●ra.

sp.speaker: Sir Godf.
sp.p: Canst thou? I will be patient, say where dwells he?

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: Marry he dwells now sir, where he would not dwell and he could choose: in the Marshalseas sir; but he's an exc'llent fellow if he were out, has travelled all the world o'er, he, and been in the seven and twenty provinces: why he would make it be fetched sir if 'twere rid a thousand mile out of town.

sp.speaker: Sir Godf.
sp.p: An admirable fellow what lies he for.

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: Why he did but rob a steward of ten groats tother night, as any man would ha' done, and there he lies fort.

sp.speaker: Sir Godf.
sp.l: I'll make his peace, a trifle, I'll get his pardon,
Beside a bountiful reward, I'll about it,
But fee the clerks, the justice will do much;
I will about it straight, good sister pardon me,
All will be well I hope, and turn to good,
The name of conjurer has laid my blood.

div.stage: Enter two sergeants to arrest the scholar George Pyeboord.

sp.speaker: Put.
sp.p: His hostesses where he lies will trust him no longer, she has feed me to arrest him; and if you will accompany me, because I know not of what nature the scholar is, whether desperate or swift, you shall share with me sergeant Raven-shaw, I have the good angel to arrest him.

sp.speaker: Rauen.
sp.p: Troth I'll take part with thee then, sergeant, not for the sake of the money so much, as for the hate I bear to a scholar: why sergeant 'tis natural in us you know to hate scholars: natural 〈◊〉, they will publish our imperfections, knaveries, and convey altars upon scaffolds and stages.

sp.speaker: Put.
sp.p: I and spitefully to; troth I have wondered how the slaves could see into our breasts so much, when our doublers are buttoned with pewter.

sp.speaker: Rauen.
sp.p: I and so close without yielding; o their perilous fellows, they will search more with their wits then a constable with all his officers.

sp.speaker: Put,
sp.p: Whist, whist, whist, yeoman Dogson, yeoman Dogson.

sp.speaker: Dog.
sp.p: Ha, what says sergeant?

sp.speaker: Put.
sp.p: Is he in the pothecaries shop still,

sp.speaker: Dog.
sp.p: Ay, I.

sp.speaker: Put.
sp.p: Have an eye, eye.

sp.speaker: Rauen.
sp.p: The best is sergeant if he be a true scholar he wears no weapon I think.

sp.speaker: Put.
sp.p: No, no, he wears no weapon.

sp.speaker: Rauen.
sp.p: Mass, I am right glad of that: 'thas put me in better heart; nay if I clutch him once, let me alone to drag him if he be stiffnecked; I have been one of the six myself, that has dragged as tall men of their hands, when their weapons have been gone as ever bastinadoed a sergeant — I have done I can tell you.

sp.speaker: Dog.
sp.p: Sergeant puttock, sergeant puttock.

sp.speaker: Put.
sp.p: Hoh.

sp.speaker: Dog.
sp.p: He's coming out single.

sp.speaker: Put.
sp.p: Peace, peace be not too greedy, let him play a little let him play a little, we'll jerk him up of a sudden, I ha' fished in my time.

sp.speaker: Rauen.
sp.p: I and caught many a fool sergeant.

sp.speaker: Pye.
sp.l: I parted now from Nicholas: the chains couched,
And the old knight has spent his rage upon't,
The widow holds me in great admiration '
For cunning art: amongst joys I am' e'en lost,
For my device can no way now be crossed,
And now I must to prison to the captain, and there —

sp.speaker: Put.
sp.p: I arrest you sir.

sp.speaker: Pye.
sp.p: O — I spoke truer than I was aware , I must to prison indeed.

sp.speaker: Put.
sp.p:
They say your a scholar, nay sir — yeoman Dogson, have
care to his arms — you'll rail again sergeants, and stage 'em: you, tickle their vices.

sp.speaker: Pye.
sp.p: Nay use me like a gentleman, I'm little less.

sp.speaker: Put.
sp.p: You a gentleman? that's a good jest i'faith; can a scholar be a gentleman, — when a gentleman will not be a scholar; — look upon your wealthy citizens' sons, whether they be scholars or no, that are gentlemen by their father's trades: a scholar a gentleman.

sp.speaker: Pye.
sp.p: Nay let fortune drive all her stings into me, she cannot hurt that in me, a gentleman, is accidens inseperabile to my blood.

sp.speaker: Rauen.
sp.p: A rabblement, nay you shall have a bloody rabblement; upon you I warrant you.

sp.speaker: Put.
sp.p: Go, yeoman Dogson before, and enter the action ith' counter.

sp.speaker: Pie.
sp.p: Pray do not hand me cruelly, I'll go,Exet Dogson.whether you please to have me,

sp.speaker: Put.
sp.p: O he's tame let him lose sergeant.

sp.speaker: Pie.
sp.p: Pray at whose suit is this?

sp.speaker: Put.
sp.p: Why at your hostesses suit where you lie, mistress Cunnyburrow for bed and board, the sum four pound five shillings and five pence.

sp.speaker: Pie.
sp.l: I know the sum too true, yet I presumed,
Upon a farther day; well 'tis my stars:
And I must bear it now, though never harder.
I swear now, my device is crossed indeed.
Captain must lie bite: this is deceits seed.

sp.speaker: Put.
sp.p: Come, come away.

sp.speaker: Pye.
sp.p: Pray give me so much time as to knit my garter, and I'll a way with you.

sp.speaker: Put.
sp.p: Well we must be paid for this waiting upon you, this is no pains to attend thus.

sp.speaker: Pye.
sp.p:
I am now wretched, and miserable, I shall ne'er recover of this disease: hot iron gnaw their fists: they have struck a fever into my shoulder, which I shall ne'er shake out again I fear me, till with a true habeas corpus the sexton remove me, o if I take prison once I shall be pressed to death with actions, but not so happy as speedily; perhaps I may be
forty year a pressing till I be a thin old man, that looking through the grates, men may look through me; all my means is confounded, what shall I do? has my wit served me so long, and now give me the slip (Like a trained servant) when I have most need of 'em: no device to keep my poor carcase from these puttocks? — yes, happiness, have I a paper about me now? yes too, I'll try it, it may hit, extremity is touchstone unto wit, ay, I.

sp.speaker: Put.
sp.p: 'Sfoot how many yards are in thy garters, that thou art so long a tying on them? come away sir.

sp.speaker: Pyb.
sp.p: Troth sergeant I protest, you could never ha' taken me at a worse time, for now at this instant, I have no lawful picture about me.

sp.speaker: Put.
sp.p: Slid how shall me come by our fees then.

sp.speaker: Ra●.
sp.p: We must have fees sirrah.

sp.speaker: Pib.
sp.p: I could ha' wished i'faith, that you had taken me half an hour hence for your own sake, for I protest if you had not crossed me, I was going in great joy to receive five pound of a gentleman, for the device of a mask here, drawn in this paper ▪ but now, come I must be contented, 'tis but so much lost, and answerable to the rest of my fortunes.

sp.speaker: Put.
sp.p: Why how far hence dwells that gentleman?

sp.speaker: Rau.
sp.p: Ay, well said sergeant, 'tis good to cast about for money.

sp.speaker: Put.
sp.p: Speak, if it be not far —

sp.speaker: Pyb.
sp.p: We are but a little passed it, the next street behind us.

sp.speaker: Put.
sp.p: Slid we have waited upon you grievously already ▪ if you'll say you'll be liberal when you hate, give us double fees, and spend upon's, why we'll show you that kindness, and go along with you to the gentleman.

sp.speaker: Rau.
sp.p: I well said still sergeant urge that.

sp.speaker: Pyb.
sp.p: Troth if it will suffice, it shall be all among you, for my part I'll not pocket a penny, my hostess shall have her four pound five shillings, and bate me the five pence, and the other fifteen shillings I'll spend upon you.

sp.speaker: Rauinsh.
sp.p: Why now thou art a good scholar.

sp.speaker: Put.
sp.p: An excellent scholar i'faith; has proceeded very well o'late; come, we'll along with you.

div.stage: Exeunt with him passing in they knock at the door with a knocker with inside.

sp.speaker: Servant
sp.p: Who knocks, who's at door? we had need of a porter.

sp.speaker: Pyb.
sp.p: A few friends here? — prey is the gentleman your master within.

sp.speaker: Servant
sp.p: Yes, is your business to him?

sp.speaker: Pyb.
sp.l: Ay, he knows it, when he see's me:
I pray you have you forgotten me.

sp.speaker: Servant
sp.p: I by my troth sir, pray come near, I'll in and tell him of you, please you to walk here in the gallery till he comes.

sp.speaker: Pyb.
sp.p: We will attend his worship, — worship I think, for so much the posts at his door should signify, and the fair coming in, and the wicket, else I neither knew him nor his worship, but 'tis happiness he is within doors, whatsoe'er he be, if he be not too much a formal citizen, he may do me good: sergeant and yeoman, how do you like this house, is't not most wholesomely plotted?

sp.speaker: Rauen.
sp.p: Troth prisoner, an exceeding fine house.

sp.speaker: Pyb.
sp.p: Yet I wonder how he should forget me, for he ne'er knew me: no matter, what is forgotten in you will be remembered in your master.
sp.l: A pretty comfortable room this methinks :
You have no such rooms in prison now?

sp.speaker: Put.
sp.p: O dog-holes toot,

sp.speaker: Pyb.
sp.p: Dog-holes indeed — I can tell you I have great hope to have my chamber here shortly, nay and diet too, for he's the most free-hartedst gentleman where he takes: you would little think it? and what a fine gallery were here for me to walk and study, and make verses,

sp.speaker: Put.
sp.p: O it stands very pleasantly for a scholar.

sp.speaker: Pyb.
sp.p: Look what maps, and pictures, and devices, and things, neatly delicately? mass here he comes, he should be a gentleman, I like his beard well; — all happiness to your worship.

sp.speaker: Gentleman
sp.p: You're kindly welcome sir.

sp.speaker: Put.
sp.p: A simple salutation.

sp.speaker: Rauen.
sp.p: Mass it seems the gentleman makes great account of him.

sp.speaker: Pyb.
sp.p: I have the thing here for you sir.

sp.speaker: Pyb.
sp.p: I beseech you conceal me sir, I'm undone else, — I have the mask here for you sir, look you sir, — I beseech your worship first to pardon my rudeness, for my extremes makes me boulder than I would be; I am a poor gentleman and a scholar, and now most unfortunately fallen into the fangs of unmerciful officers, arrested for debt, which though small, I am not able to compass, by reason I'm destitute of lands, money, and friends, so that if I fall into the hungry swallow of the prison, I am like utterly to perish, and with fees and extortions be pinched clean to the bone: now, if ever pity had interest in the blood of a gentleman, I beseech you vouchsafe but to favour that means of my escape, which I have already thought upon.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.p: Go forward.

sp.speaker: Put.
sp.p: I warrant he likes it rarely.

sp.speaker: Pyb.
sp.p: In the plunge of my extremities, being giddy, and doubtful what to do; at last it was put into my labouring thoughts, to make happy use of this paper, and to blear their unlettered eyes, I told them there was a device for a mask drawn int', and that (But for their interception,) I was going to a gentleman to receive my reward for't: they greedy at this word, and hoping to make purchase of me, offered their attendance, to go along with me,' my hap was to make bold with your door sir, which my thoughts showed me the most fairest and comfortablest entrance, and I hope I have happened right upon understanding, and pity: may it please your good worship then, but to uphold my device, which is to let one of your men put me out at backdoor, and I shall be bound to your worship for ever.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.p: By my troth an excellent device.

sp.speaker: Puttock.
sp.p: An excellent device he says; he likes it wonderfully.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.p: A my faith I never heard a better.

sp.speaker: Ravenshaw.
sp.p: Hark, he swears he never heard a better, sergeant.

sp.speaker: Put.
sp.p: O there's no talk on't, he's an excellent scholar, and especially for a mask.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.p: Give me your paper, your device; I was never better pleased in all my life: good wit, brave wit, finely wrought, come in sir, and receive your money sir.

sp.speaker: Pyb.
sp.l: I'll follow your good worship, —
You heard how he liked it now?

sp.speaker: Put.
sp.p: Puh, we know he could not choose but like it: go thy ways thou art a witty fine fellow i'faith, thou shalt discourse it to us at tavern anon wilt thou?

sp.speaker: Pyb
sp.p: Ay, ay, that I will, — look sergeants here are maps, and pretty toys, be doing in the mean time, I shall quickly have told out the money, you know.

sp.speaker: Put.
sp.p: Go, go little villain, fetch thy chink, I begin to love thee, I'll be drunk tonight in thy company.

sp.speaker: Pyb.
sp.l: This gentlemen I may well call a part
Of my salvation, in these earthly evils,
For he has saved me from three hungry devils.

sp.speaker: Puttock ▪
sp.p: Sirrah sergeant, these maps are pretty painted things, but I could ne'er fancy 'em yet, ●mee thinks they're too busy, and full of circles and conjurations, they say all the world's in one of them, but I could ne'er find the counter in the poultry.

sp.speaker: Raue.
sp.p: I think so: how could you find it? for you know it stands behind the houses.

sp.speaker: Dogson.
sp.p: Mass that's true, than we must look ath' backside fort; sfoot here's nothing, all's bare.

sp.speaker: Rauen.
sp.p: I warrant thee that stands for the counter, for you know there's a company of bare fellows there.

sp.speaker: Put.
sp.p: Faith like enough sergeant? I never marked so much before? Sirrah sergeant, and yeoman, I should love these maps out a cry now, if we could see if peep out of door in 'em, o we might have 'em in a morning to our breakfast so finely, and ne'er knock our heels to the ground a whole day for 'em.

sp.speaker: Rauen.
sp.l: I marry sir, I'd buy one then myself.
But this talk is by the way, where shall's sup tonight ,
Five pound received, let's talk of that,
sp.p: I have a trick worth all, you two shall bear him to'th tavern, whilst I go close with his hostess, and work out of her, I know she would be glad of the sum to finger money; because she knows 'tis but a desperate debt, and full of hazard, what will you say if I bring it to pass that the hostess shall be contented with one half for all; and we to share tother; fifth-shillings bullies.

sp.speaker: Put.
sp.p: Why I would call thee King of sergeants, and thou shouldst be chronicled in the counter book for ever.

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.p: Well put it to me, we'll make a night on't faith.

sp.speaker: Dog.
sp.p: Sfoot I think he receives more money he stays so long.

sp.speaker: Put.
sp.p: He tarries long indeed, may be I can tell you upon the good liking on't the gentleman may prove more bountiful.

sp.speaker: Ra
sp.p: That would be rare, we'll search him.

sp.speaker: Put.
sp.p: Nay be sure of it we'll search him! and make him light enough.

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.p: O here comes the gentleman; by your leave sir.

sp.speaker: Gentleman
sp.p: God you god den sirs, — would you speak with me;

sp.speaker: Put.
sp.p: No, not with your worship sir, only we are bold to stay for a friend of ours that went in with your worship.

sp.speaker: Gentleman
sp.p: Who? not the scholar?

sp.speaker: Put.
sp.p: Yes e'en he and it please your worship?

sp.speaker: Gentleman
sp.p: Did he make you stay for him? he did you wrong then why, I can assure you he's gone above an hour ago.

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.p: How? sir?

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.p: I paid him his money, and my man told me he went out at backdoor.

sp.speaker: Put.
sp.p: Backdoor?

sp.speaker: Gentleman
sp.p: Why, what's the matter.

sp.speaker: Put.
sp.p: He was our prisoner sir, we did arrest him.

sp.speaker: Gentleman
sp.l: What he was not? you the sheriff's officers — you were to blame then,
Why did you not make known to me as much:
I could have kept him for you, I protest
He received all of me in Britain gold
Of the last coining;

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.p: Vengeance dog him with't.

sp.speaker: Put.
sp.p: Sfoot has he gulled us so.

sp.speaker: Dog.
sp.p: Where shall we sup now sergeants?

sp.speaker: Put.
sp.l: Sup Simon now, eat porridge for a month;
sp.p: Well, we cannot impute it to any lack of goodwill in your worship, — you did but as another would have done, 'twas our hard fortunes to miss the purchase, but if ere we clutch him again, the counter shall charm him.

sp.speaker: Ra●e●.
sp.p: The hole shall rotten him.

sp.speaker: Dog.
sp.p: Amen.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: So,
Vex out your lungs without doors, I am proud,
It was my hap to help him, it fell fit,
He went not empty neither for his wit ▪
Alas poor wretch, I could not blame his brain,
To labour his delivery, to be free,
From their unpitying fangs — I'm glad it stood,
Within my power to do a scholar good.

div.stage: Enter in the prison, meeting George and captain, George coming in muffle.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: How now, who's that? what are you?

sp.speaker: Pyb
sp.p: The same that I should be captain.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: George Pie-board, honest George? why camest thou in half faced muffled so?

sp.speaker: Pyb.
sp.p: O captain, I thought we should ne'er ha' laughed again, never spent frolic hour again.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: Why? why?

sp.speaker: Pyb
sp.l: I coming to prepare thee, and with news
As happy as thy quick delivery,
Was traced out by the sent, arrested captain.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: Arrested George.

sp.speaker: Pyb.
sp.p: Arrested, guess, guess, how many dogs do you think I'd upon me?

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: Dogs, I say? I know not.

sp.speaker: Pyb.
sp.l: Almost as many as George stone the bear,
Three at once, three at once.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: How didst thou shake 'em of then?

sp.speaker: Pyb.
sp.l: The time is busy, and calls upon our wits, let it suffice,
Here I stand safe, and scaped by miracle,
Some other hour shall tell thee? when we'll steep
Our eyes in laughter: captain my device
Leans to thy happiness, for ere the day
Be spent toth' girdle, thou shalt be set free,
The corporal's in his first sleep the chain is missed,
Thy kinsman has expressed thee, and the old knight
With pali●y-hams now labours thy release,
What rests, is all in thee, to conjure captain.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: Conjure: sfoot George you know the devil a conjuring I can conjure.

sp.speaker: P●b.
sp.p: The devil of conjuring nay by my fay, I'd not have thee do so much captain as the devil a conjuring: look here, I ha' brought thee a circle ready charactered and all.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: Sfoot George, art in thy right wits, dost know what thou sayest? why dost talk to a captain, a conjuring, didst thou ever hear of a captain conjure in thy life, dost cal't a circle, 'tis too wide a thing my thinks: had it been a lesser circle, than I knew what to have done.

sp.speaker: Pib.
sp.p: Why every fool knows that captain: nay then I'll not cog with you captain, if you'll stay and hang the next sessions you may.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: No by my faith George, come, come, let's to conjuring, let's to conjuring.

sp.speaker: Pib.
sp.p: But if you look to be released, as my wits have taken pain to work it, and all means wrought to farther it, besides to put crowns in your purse, to make you a man of better hopes, and where as before you were a captain or poor soldier, to make you now a commander of rich fools, (Which is truly the only best purchase peace can allow you) safer than highways, heath, or cunny-groves, and yet a far better booty; for your greatest thieves are never hanged, never hanged, for why they're wise, and cheat within doors, and we geld fools of more money in one night, than your false tailed gelding will purchase in a twelvemonth's running, which confirms the old beldames saying, he's wisest, that keeps himself warmest, that is, he that robs by a good fire.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: Well opened i'faith George, thou hast pulled that saying out of the husk.

sp.speaker: Pib.
sp.p: Captain idle, 'tis no time now to delude or delay, the old knight will be here suddenly, I'll perfect you, direct you, till you the trick on't: 'tis nothing.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: Sfoot George, I know not what to say to't, conjure? I shall be hanged ere I conjure.

sp.speaker: Pyb.
sp.p: Nay tell not me of that captain, you'll ne'er conjure after your hanged, I warrant you look you sir, a perilous matter? sure, first to spread your circle upon the ground, then with a little conjuring ceremony, as I'll have an hackney-man's wand silvered o'er a purpose for you, then arriving in the circle, with a huge word, and a great trample as for instance: have you never seen a stalking-stamping player, that will raise a tempest with his tongue, and thunder with his heels?

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: O yes, yes, yes: often, often.

sp.speaker: Pyb.
sp.p: Why be like such a one, for any thing will blear the old knights eyes, for you must note that he'll ne'er dare to venture into the room, only perhaps peep fearfully through the key hole, to see how the play goes forward.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: Well I may go about it when I will, but mark the end on't, I shall but shame myself i'faith George, speak big words, and stamp and stare and he look in at keyhole, why the very thought of that would make me laugh outright, and spoil all, nay I'll tell thee George, when I apprehend a thing once, I am of such a laxative laughter, that if the devil himself stood by, I should laugh in his face.

sp.speaker: Pyb.
sp.p: Puh, that's but the babe of a man, and may easily be hushed, as to think upon some disaster, some sad misfortune, as the death of thy father i'the country!

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: Sfoot that would be the more to drive me into such an ecstasy, that I should ne'er lin laughing.

sp.speaker: Pib.
sp.p: Why then think upon going to hanging else.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: Mass that's well remembered, now I'll do well I warrant thee, ne'er fear me now: but how shall I do George for boisterous words, and horrible names.

sp.speaker: Pyb.
sp.p: Puh, any fustian invocations captain will serve as well as the best, so you rant them out well, or you may go to a pothecary's shop, and take all the words from the boxes.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: Troth and you say true George, there's strange words enough to raise a hundred quacksalvers; though they be ne'er so poor when they begin? but here lies the fear on't, how in this false conjuration a true devil should pop up indeed.

sp.speaker: Pyb.
