sp.p: A true devil, captain, why there was ne'er such a one, nay faith he that has this place, is as false a knave as our last churchwarden.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: Then he's false enough a conscience i'faith George.

sp.speaker: Cry prisoners.
sp.l: Good gentlemen over the way, send your relief,
Good gentlemen over the way, — good sir Godfrey?

sp.speaker: Pyb.
sp.p: He's come, he's come.

sp.speaker: Nich.
sp.p: Master, that's my kinsman yonder in the buff-jerkin — kinsman, that's my master yonder ith' taffety hat — pray salute him entirely?

div.stage: They salute: and Pyeboord salutes master Edmond.

sp.speaker: Sir God.
sp.p: Now my friend.

sp.speaker: Pib.
sp.p: May I partake your name sir.

sp.speaker: Edm.
sp.p: My name is master edmunded.

sp.speaker: Pyb.
sp.p: Master Edmond — are you not a Welshman sir?

sp.speaker: Edm.
sp.p: A Welshman, why?

sp.speaker: Pyb.
sp.p: Because master is your Christen name, and Edmond your sir name?

sp.speaker: Edm.
sp.p: O no; I have more names at home, master Edmund Pius, is my full name at length.

sp.speaker: P●b.
sp.p: O cry you mercy sir?

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: I understand that you are my kinsman's good master, and in regard of that, the best of my skill is at your service: but had you fortuned a mere stranger, and made no means to me by acquaintance, I should have utterly denied to have been the man; both by reason of the act passed in parliament against conjurers and witches, as also, because I would not have my art vulgar, trite, and common.

sp.speaker: Sir Godf.
sp.p: I much commend your care therein good captain conjurer, and that I will be sure to have it private enough, you shall do't in my sister's house, — mine own house I may call it, for both our charges therein are proportioned.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: Very good sir — what may I call your loss sir?

sp.speaker: Sir Godf.
sp.p: O you may call't a great loss sir, a grievous loss sir, as goodly a chain of gold, though I say it, that wore it: how sayest thou Nicholas?

sp.speaker: Nich.
sp.p: O 'twas as delicious a chain a gold, kinsman you know, —

sp.speaker: Sir God.
sp.p: You know? did you know't captain?

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: Trust a fool with secrets? — sir he may say I know: his meaning is, because my art is such, that by it I may gather a knowledge of all things. —

sp.speaker: Sir Godf.
sp.p: I very true.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: A pax of all fools — the excuse stuck upon my tongue like ship-pitch upon a mariner's gown, not to come off in haste — by’r lady knight to lose such a fair chain a gold, were a soul loss; well, I can put you in this good comfort on't, if it be between heaven and earth knight, I'll have't for you?

sp.speaker: Sir God.
sp.p: A wonderful conjurer, — oh ay, 'tis between heaven and earth I warrant you, it cannot go out of the realm, — I know 'tis somewhere above the earth?

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: I nigher the earth than thou worst on.

sp.speaker: Sir Goaf.
sp.p: For first my chain was rich, and no rich thing shall enter into heaven you know?

sp.speaker: Nich.
sp.p: And as for the devil master, he has no need on't, for you know he has a great chain of his own?

sp.speaker: Sir Godf.
sp.p: Thou sayest true Nicholas, but he has put off that now, that lies by him.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: Faith knight in few words, I presume so much upon the power of my art; that I could warrant your chain again.

sp.speaker: Sir Godf.
sp.p: O dainty captain?

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: Marry it will cost me much sweat, I were better go to sixteen whore-houses.

sp.speaker: Sir Godf.
sp.p: I good man, I warrant thee.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: Beside great vexation of kidney and liver.

sp.speaker: Nich.
sp.p: O 'twill tickle you hereabouts cozen, because you have not been used to't.

sp.speaker: Sir Godf.
sp.p: No, have you not been used to't captain?

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p:
Plague of all 〈…〉 — indeed knight I have not
used it a good while, and therefore 'twill strain me so much the more you know.

sp.speaker: Sir Godf.
sp.p: On it will, it will.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: What plunges he puts me to, were not this knight a fool, I had been twice spoilt now; that captain's worse then accursed that has an ass to his kinsman — sfoot I fear he will drivel't out before I come to't. — now sir — to come to the point in deed — you see I stick here in the jaw of the Marshalsea, and cannot do't.

sp.speaker: Sir Godf.
sp.p: Tut tur I now thy meaning, thou wouldst say thou'rt a prisoner, I tell thee thou'rt none.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: How none? why is not this the Marshalsea?

sp.speaker: Sir Godf.
sp.p: Wilt hear me speak, I hard of thy rare conjuring my chain was lost, I sweat for thy release, as thou shalt do the like at home for me, keeper.

sp.speaker: Keeper
sp.p: Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Godf.
sp.p: Speak is not this man free?

sp.speaker: Keeper
sp.p: Yes at his pleasure sir, the fees discharged;

sp.speaker: Sir Godf.
sp.p: Go, go, I'll discharge them I.

sp.speaker: Keeper
sp.p: I thank your worship

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: Now trust me you're a dear knight kindness unexpected, o theirs nothing to a free gentle man. — I will conjure for you sir till froth come through my buff-jerkin?

sp.speaker: Sir Godf.
sp.p: Nay then thou shalt not pass with so little a bounty, for at the first sight of my chain again, — forty fine angels shall appear unto thee.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: 'Twill be a glorious show, i'faith knight a very fine show, but are all these of your own house? are you sure of that fir?

sp.speaker: Sir Godf.
sp.p: Ay, ay, no, no, what's he yonder? talking with my wild nephew, pray heaven, he give him good counsel;

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: Who he he's a rare friend of mine, an admirable fellow knight, the finest fortune-teller.

sp.speaker: Sir Godf.
sp.p:
O 'tis he indeed that came to my lady sister, and foretold the loss of my chain, I am not angry with him now, for I see 'twas my fortune to lose it; by your leave m. fortune-teller, I had a glimpse on you at home at my sisters the widows, there you prophesied of the loss of a chain, — simply though I stand
here I was he that lost it.

sp.speaker: Pie.
sp.p: Was it you sir?

sp.speaker: Edn.
sp.p: A my troth nuncle, he's the rarest fellow, has told me my fortune so right; I find it so right to my nature.

sp.speaker: Sir Godf.
sp.p: What is't? God send it a good one?

sp.speaker: Ed●n.
sp.p: O 'tis a passing good one, nuncle: for he says I shall prove such an excellent gamester in my time, that I shall spend all faster than my father got it,

sp.speaker: Sir Godf.
sp.p: There's a fortune in deed,

sp.speaker: Edm.
sp.p: Nay it hits my humour so pat.

sp.speaker: Sir Godf.
sp.p: I that will be the end on't. will the curse of the beggar prevail so much, that the son shall consume that foolishly, which the father got, craftily, ay, ay, ay, 'twill, 'twill, 'twill.

sp.speaker: Pie.
sp.p: Stay, stay, stay

div.stage: Pyeboord with an almanac and the captain.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: Turn over George.

sp.speaker: Pie.
sp.p: June July, here July that's this month, Sunday thirteen, yesterday fourteen, today fifteen.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: Look quickly for the fifteen day, — if within the compass of these two days there would be some boisterous storm or other, it would be the best, I'd defer him off till then, some tempest and it be thy will?

sp.speaker: Pie
sp.p: Here's the fifteen day — hot and fair.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: Puh, would t'ad been hot and foul.

sp.speaker: Pie.
sp.p: The sixteen day, that's tomorrow, the morning for the most part fair and pleasant.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: No luck.

sp.speaker: Pie
sp.p: But about high-noon-lightning and thunder.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: Lightning and thunder, admirable, best of all, I'll conjure tomorrow just at hie none George.

sp.speaker: Pye.
sp.p: Happen but true tomorrow almanac, and I'll give thee leave to lie all the year after.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: Sir I must crave your patience, to bestow this day upon me, that I may furnish myself strongly, — I sent a spirit into Lancashire tother day, to fetch back a knave drover, and I look for his return this evening — tomorrow morning my friend here and I will come and breakfast with you.

sp.speaker: Sir Godf.
sp.p: O you shall be both most welcome.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: And about noon without fail, I purpose to conjure.

sp.speaker: Sir Godf.
sp.p: Mid noon will be a fine time for you.

sp.speaker: Edm.
sp.p: Conjuring, do you mean to conjure at our house tomorrow sir?

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: Marry do I sir ? 'tis my intent young gentleman.

sp.speaker: Edm.
sp.p: By my troth, I'll love you while I live sort, oh rare, Nicholas we shall have conjuring, to morrow,

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: Puh ay, I could ha' told you of that.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: Law he could ha' told him of that, fool, coxcomb could ye.

sp.speaker: Edm
sp.p: Do you hear me sir, I desire more acquaintance on you, you shall earn some money of me, now I know you can conjure, but can you fetch any that is lost?

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: O any thing that's lost.

sp.speaker: Edm.
sp.p: Why look you sir, I tel't you as a friend and a conjurer, I should marry a pothecary's daughter and 'twas told me she lost her maiden head at Stony-stratford; now if you'll do but so much as conjure fort, and make all whole again. —

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: That I will sir.

sp.speaker: Edm.
sp.p: By my troth I thank you la,

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: A little merry with your sister's son sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Godf.
sp.p: O a simple young man, very simple, come captain, and you sir, we'll e'en part with a gallon of wine till tomorrow breakfast.

sp.speaker: Tipstaff captain
sp.p: Troth agreed sir.

sp.speaker: Nic
sp.p: Kinsman — scholar?

sp.speaker: Pye.
sp.p: Why now thou art a good knave, worth a hundred brownists.

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: Am I indeed la: I thank you truly la.

div.head: Actus. 4.
div.stage: Enter Moll, and sir John Pennydub.

sp.speaker: Penne.
sp.p: But I hope you will not serve a knight so: gentlewoman will you: to cashier him, and cast him off at your pleasure; what do you think I was dubbed for nothing, no by my faith lady's daughter.

sp.speaker: Moll.
sp.p: Pray sir John Pennydub, let it be deferred awhile, I have as big a heart to marry as you can have; but as the fortune-teller told me.

sp.speaker: Penny.
sp.p:
I axe a'th fortune-teller, would Derrick had been
his fortune seven year ago, to cross my love them: did he know what case I was in, why this is able to make a man drown himself in's father's fishpond.

sp.speaker: Moll.
sp.p: And then he told me moreover sir John, that the breach of it, kept my father in purgatory.

sp.speaker: Penny.
sp.p: In purgatory? why let him purge out his heart there, what have we to do with that? there's physicians enough there to cast his water, is that any matter to us: how can he hinder our love, why let him bew changed now he's dead? — well, have I rid post day and night, to bring you merry news of my father's death, and now —

sp.speaker: Moll.
sp.p: Thy father's death? is the old farmer dead?

sp.speaker: Penny.
sp.p: As dead as his barn door Moll.

sp.speaker: Moll,
sp.p: And you'll keep your word with me now, sir John. that I shall have my coach and my coachman?

sp.speaker: Penny.
sp.p: i'faith.

sp.speaker: Moll.
sp.p: And two white horses with black feathers to draw it?

sp.speaker: Penny.
sp.p: Too,

sp.speaker: Moll.
sp.p: A guarded lackey to run before't, and pied liveries to come trashing after't.

sp.speaker: 〈◊〉 Penny.
sp.p: Thou shalt Moll.

sp.speaker: Moll.
sp.p: And to let me have money in my purse to go whether I will.

sp.speaker: Penny.
sp.p: All this.

sp.speaker: Moll.
sp.p: Then come, whatsoe'er comes on't, we'll be made sure together before the maids a'the kitchen.

div.stage: Enter widow, with her eldest daughter Frank and frailty.

sp.speaker: Widow
sp.p: How now? where's my brother sir Godfrey? went he forth this morning?

sp.speaker: Frail.
sp.p: O no madam, he's above at breakfast, with sir reverence a conjurer.

sp.speaker: Widow
sp.p: A conjurer? what manner a fellow is he?

sp.speaker: Frail.
sp.p: O, a wondrous rare fellow mistress, very strongly made upward, for he goes in a buff-jerkin: he says he will fetch sir Godfrey's chain again, if it hang between heaven and earth.

sp.speaker: Widow
sp.p:
What he will not? then he's an exc'llent fellow I warrant. how happy were that woman to be blessed with such a husband, a man a cunning? how does he look frailty: very swartly I
warrant, with black beard, scorched cheeks, and smoky eyebrows.

sp.speaker: Frail.
sp.p: Fooh — he's neither smoke-dried, nor scorched, nor black, nor nothing, I tell you madam, he looks as fair to see to, as one of us; I do not think but if you saw him once, you'd take him to be a christian.

sp.speaker: Frank
sp.p: So fair, and yet so cunning, that's to be wondered at mother.

div.stage: Enter sir Oliver Muckhill, and sir Andrew tipstaff.

sp.speaker: Muck.
sp.p: Bless you sweet lady.

sp.speaker: Tip
sp.p: And you fair mistress.

sp.speaker: Widow
sp.p: Coades? what do you mean gentlemen? fie, did I not give you your answers?

sp.speaker: Muck.
sp.p: Sweet lady?

sp.speaker: Widow
sp.l: Well, I will not stick with you now for a kiss,
Daughter kiss the gentleman for once.

sp.speaker: Frank
sp.p: Yes forsooth.

sp.speaker: Tipstaff
sp.p: I'm proud of such a favour.

sp.speaker: Widow
sp.p: Truly la, sir Oliver, y' are much to blame to come again, when you know my mind, so well delivered — as a widow could deliver a thing.

sp.speaker: Muck.
sp.p: But I expect a farther comfort lady.

sp.speaker: Widow
sp.p: Why la you now, did I not desire you to put off your suit quite and clean, when you came to me again, how say you did I not ▪

sp.speaker: Muc.
sp.p: But the sincere love which my heart bears you,

sp.speaker: Widow
sp.p: Go to, I'll cut you off. And sir Oliver to put you in comfort afar off, my fortune is read me, I must marry again.

sp.speaker: Muck.
sp.p: O blessed fortune!

sp.speaker: Widow
sp.p: But not as long as I can choose; — nay I'll hold out, well.

sp.speaker: Muc.
sp.p: Yet are my hopes now fairer.

sp.speaker: Frail
sp.p: O madam madam.

sp.speaker: Widow
sp.p: How now, what's the haste?

sp.speaker: Tipstaff
sp.p: Faith mistress Francis I'll maintain you gallantly. I'll bring you to court, wean you among the fair society of lady's poor kinswomen of mine in cloth of silver, beside you shall have your monkey, your parrot, your muskat, and your piss, piss, piss.

sp.speaker: Frank
sp.p: It will do very well.

sp.speaker: Widow
sp.p:
What dos he mean to conjure here the? how shall I do to
be tid of these knights, — please you gentlemen to walk a while ith' garden, go gather a pink, or a jilly-flower.

sp.speaker: Both.
sp.p: With all our hearts lady, and count us favoured?

sp.speaker: Si. Go.
sp.p: Step in Nicholas, look, is the coast clear.

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: O, as clear as a cat's eye, sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Go.
sp.p: Then enter captain Conisurer? — now — how like you your room su?

div.stage: Enter sir Godf. Capt. Pyb. Edm. Nick.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: O wonderful convenient.

sp.speaker: Ed●●.
sp.p: I can tell you captain, simply though it lies here, 'tis the fairest room in my mother's house, as dainty a room to conjure in, methinks , — why you may bid, I cannot tell how many devils welcome in't; my father has had twenty here at once!

sp.speaker: Pie.
sp.p: What devils?

sp.speaker: Edn.
sp.p: Devils, no deputies, and the wealthiest men he could get.

sp.speaker: Sir God.
sp.p: Nay put by your chattels now, fall to your business roundly, the seskewe of the dial is upon the christ-cross of noon, but o: hear met captain, a qualm comes o'er my stomach?

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: Why, what's the matter sir?

sp.speaker: Sir Godf.
sp.p: O, how if the devil should prove a knave, and tear the hangings.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: Fuh, I warrant you sir Godfrey:

sp.speaker: Edm.
sp.p: I nuncle, or spit fire upp'oth feeling!

sp.speaker: Sir Godf
sp.p: Very true too, for 'tis but thin plastered, and 'twill quickly take hold a the laths, and if he chance to spit downward-to, he will burn all the boards.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: My life for yours sir Godfrey?

sp.speaker: Sir Godf.
sp.p: My sister is very curious and dainty o'er this room I can tell and therefore if he must needs spit, I pray desire him to spit ith' chimney.

sp.speaker: Pie.
sp.p: Why assure you sir Godfrey, he shall not be brought up, with so little manners to spit and spawl a'th flower.

sp.speaker: Sir Godf.
sp.p: Why I thank you good captain, pray have a care I, fall to your circle, we'll not trouble you I warrant you, come, we'll in to the next room, and because we'll be sure to keep him out there, we'll bar up the door with some of the godlies zealous works.

sp.speaker: Edm.
sp.p: That will be a fine device nuncle, and because the ground shall be as holy as the door, I'll tear two or three refaires in pieces, and strew the leaves about the chamber? o, the devil already, — runs in —

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.p: Sfoot captain speak somewhat for shame; it lightens and thunders before thou wilt begin, why when?

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: Pray peace George, — thou'lt make me laugh anon; and spoil all.

sp.speaker: Pie.
sp.p: O now it begins again, now, now? now? Captain?

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: Rumbos-ragdayon, pur, pur, colucundrion, Hois — Plois.

sp.speaker: Sir Godf.
sp.p: O admirable conjurer? has fetched thunder already:

div.stage: Sir Godfrey through the keyhole? within.

sp.speaker: Pie.
sp.p: Hark hark again captain?

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: Beniamino, — gaspois — kay — gosgothoteron — umbrois.

sp.speaker: Sir Godf.
sp.p: O, I would the devil would come away quickly, he has no conscience to put a man to such pain?

sp.speaker: Pie.
sp.p: Again!

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: Flow'st — kakopumpos — dragon — leloomenos — hodge — podge.

sp.speaker: Pie.
sp.p: Well said captain.

sp.speaker: Sir Godf.
sp.p: So long a coming? o would I had ne'er begun't now, for I fear me these roaring tempests, will destroy all the fruits of the earth, and tread upon my come — o, ith' country.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: Gog de gog, hobgoblin, hunks, houseslow, hockley te come park.

sp.speaker: Widow
sp.p: O brother, brother, what a tempest's ith', garden, sure there's some conjuration abroad.

sp.speaker: Sir Godf.
sp.p: 'Tis at home sister!

sp.speaker: Pie.
sp.p: By and by, I'll step in? Captain?

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: Nunck — nunck — rip — Gascoynes, ipis, Drip — dropite.

sp.speaker: Sir God.
sp.p: He drips and drops poor man? alas, alas.

sp.speaker: Pie.
sp.p: Now I come?

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: O sulphur Scoteface —

sp.speaker: Pie
sp.p: Arch-conjurer, what wouldst thou with me?

sp.speaker: Sir Godf.
sp.l: O the devil sister, ith' dining chamber, sing sister,
I warrant you that will keep him out, quickly, quickly, quickly. goes in.

sp.speaker: Pie.
sp.p:
So, so, so, I'll release thee, enough captain, enough,
allow us some time to laugh a little, they're shuddering and shaking by this time, as if an earthquake were in their kidneys.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: Sirrah George, how wast, how wast, did I do't well enough.

sp.speaker: Pit.
sp.p: Wilt believe me captain, better than any conjurer, for here was no harm in this, and yet their horrible expectation satisfied well, you were much beholding to thunder and lightning at this time it gracst you well I can tell you?

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: I must needs say so George? sirrah if we could ha' convoyed hither cleanly a cracker or a fire-wheel t'ad been admittable.

sp.speaker: Pit.
sp.p: Blutt, blutt theirs nothing remains to put thee to pain now captain.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: Pain? I protest George my heels are sorer, than a Whitsun morris-dancer.

sp.speaker: Pie.
sp.l: All's past now, — only to reveal that the chains ith'
Garden where thou knowest it has lain these two days.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.l: But I fear that fox Nicholas has revealed it already?

sp.speaker: Pie.
sp.l: Fear not captain, you must put it to'th venture now
Nay 'tis time, call upon 'em, take pity on 'em, for I believe
Some off 'em are in a pitiful case by this time.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: Sir Godfrey? Nicholas, kinsman-sfoot they're fast at it still George, sir Godfrey?

sp.speaker: Sir Godf.
sp.p: O, is that the devil's voice? how comes he to know my name.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: Fear not sir Godfrey all's quieted.

sp.speaker: Sir Godf.
sp.p: What is he laid?

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: Layded; and has newly dropped, your chain ith' garden.

sp.speaker: Sir Godf.
sp.p: Ith' garden! in our garden?

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: Your garden?

sp.speaker: Sir Godf.
sp.p: O sweet conjurer? whereabouts there?

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: Look-well about a bank of rosemary.

sp.speaker: Sir Godf.
sp.p: Sister the rosemary bank, come, come, there's my chain he says.

sp.speaker: Widow
sp.p: O happiness, run, run.

sp.speaker: Edn.
sp.p: Captain conjurer?

div.stage: Supposed to go. Edm at keyhoole.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: Who? Master Edmond.

sp.speaker: Edm.
sp.p: I master Edmond may I come in safely, without danger think you.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.l: I uh long ago, 'tis all, as 'twas at first.
Fear nothing, pray come near — how now? man.

sp.speaker: Edm.
sp.p: O this rooms mightily hot i'faith, slid my shirt sticks to my belly already, what a steam the rogue has left be hind him 'Foh this room must be air gentlemen it smells horribly of brimstone — let's open the windows.

sp.speaker: Pye
sp.p: Faith master Edmond 'tis but your conceit,

sp.speaker: Edm.
sp.p: I would you could make me believe that i'faith why do you think I cannot smell his savour, from another: yet I take it kindly from you, because you would not put me in a fear i'faith, a my troth I shall love you for this the longest day of my life.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: Puh, 'tis nothing sir, love me when you see more.

sp.speaker: Edm.
sp.p: Mass now I remember I'll look whether he has singed the hangings or no.

sp.speaker: Pye.
sp.p: Captain, to entertain a little sport till they come; make him believe, you'll charm him invisible, he's apt to admire any thing you see let me alone to give force to't.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: Go, retire, to yonder end then.

sp.speaker: Edm.
sp.p: I protest you are a rare fellow, are you not.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: O master Edmond, you know but the least part of me yet, why now at this instant I could but flourish my wand thrice o'er your head, and charm you invisible.

sp.speaker: Edm.
sp.p: What you could not? make me walk invisible man; I should laugh at that i'faith, troth I'll requite your kindness and you'll do't good captain conjurer.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: Nay I should hardly deny you such a small kindness master Edmond plus, why look you sir 'tis no more but this and thus and again and now you're invisible!

sp.speaker: Edm '
sp.p: Am i'faith, who would think it.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: You see the fortune-teller yonder at farther end ath' chamber go towards him, do what you will with him he shall ne'er find you.

sp.speaker: Edm.
sp.p: Say you so, I'll try that i'faith, —

sp.speaker: Pi●.
sp.p: How now? Captain, who's that justled me?

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: Justled you? I saw nobody .

sp.speaker: Edm.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha, — say 'twas a spirit,

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: Shall i — may be some spirit that haunts the circle.

sp.speaker: Pye.
sp.p: O my nose, again, pray conjure than captain.

sp.speaker: Edm.
sp.p: Troth this is exc'llent, I may do any knavery now and never be seen, and now I remember me, sir Godfrey my uncle abused me tother day, and told tales of me to my mother — troth now I'm invisible, I'll hit him a sound wherrit ath' ear, when he comes out ath' garden, — I may be revenged on him now finely.

div.stage: Enter sir Godfrey, widow, Frank, Nicholas with the chain.

sp.speaker: Sir God.
sp.l: I have my chain again, my chain's found again,
Oh sweet captain, oh admirable conjurer. Edm. strikes him.
O what mean you by that nephew?

sp.speaker: Edm.
sp.p: Nephew? I hope you do not know me uncle?

sp.speaker: Widow
sp.p: Why did you strike your uncle sir?

sp.speaker: Edm.
sp.p: Why captain am I not invisible?

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.l: A goodiest Georg:, — not now you are not sir,
Why did you not see me when I did uncharm you?

sp.speaker: Edm.
sp.l: Not I by my troth captain:
Then pray you pardon me uncle,
I thought I'd been invisible when I struck you.

sp.speaker: Sir Godf.
sp.l: So. you would do't? go, — you're a foolish boy,
And were I not o'ercome with greater joy,
I'd make you taste correction.

sp.speaker: Edm.
sp.p: Correction, push — no, neither you nor my mother shall think to whip me as you have done.

sp.speaker: Sir Godf.
sp.p: Captain my joy is such, I know not how to thank you, let me embrace you, hug you, oh my sweet chain, gladness 'E'en makes me giddy, rare man: 'twas as just ith' rosemary bauck, as if one should ha' laid it there — o cunning, cunning!

sp.speaker: W●d.
sp.p:
Well, seeing my fortune tells me I must marry; let me marry a man of wit a man of parts, here's a worthy captain, and 'tis a fine title truly is to be a captain's wife, a captain's wife, it goes very finely. beside all the world knows that a worthy captain, is a fit companion to any lord,
then why not a sweet bedfellow for any lady. — I'll have it so —

sp.speaker: Frail.
sp.p: O mistress, gentlemen, there's the bravest sight coming along this way.

sp.speaker: Widow
sp.p: What brave sight?

sp.speaker: Frai.
sp.p: O, one going to burying, and another going to hanging.

sp.speaker: Widow
sp.p: A rueful sight.

sp.speaker: Pyb
sp.p: 'Sfoot captain, I'll pawn my life the corporals coffined, and old skirmish the soldier going to execution, and 'tis now full about the time of his walking; hold out a little longer sleepy potion, and we shall have exc'llent admiration; for I'll take upon me the cure of him.

div.stage: Enter the coffin of the corporal, the soldier bound, and lead by officers, the sheriff there.

sp.speaker: Frail.
sp.p: O here they come, here they come!

sp.speaker: Pyb.
sp.p: Now must I close secretly with the soldier, prevent his impatience, or else all's discovered?

sp.speaker: Widow
sp.p: O lamentable seeing, these were those brothers, that sought and bled before our door.

sp.speaker: Sir Godf.
sp.p: What they were not sister?

sp.speaker: Ski●m.
sp.p: George, look to't, I'll peach at Tyburn else.

sp.speaker: Pyb.
sp.p: Mum, — gentles all, vouchsafe me audience, and you especially master sheriff:
sp.l: Yond man is bound to 〈◊〉,
Because he wounded this that now lies coffined?

sp.speaker: Sheriff
sp.p: True, true, he shall have the law, — and I know the law?

sp.speaker: Pyb.
sp.p: But under favour master sheriff, if this man had been cured and safe again, he should have been released then?

sp.speaker: Sheriff
sp.p: Why make you question of that sir?

sp.speaker: Pyb.
sp.p: Then I release him freely, and will take upon me the death that he should die, if within a little season, I do not cure him to his proper health again.

sp.speaker: Sheriff
sp.l: How sir? recover a dead man?
That were most strange of all.

sp.speaker: Frank
sp.p: Sweet sir, I love you dear, and could wish my best part yours, — o do not undertake such an impossible venture.

sp.speaker: Pyb.
sp.l: Love you me; then for your sweet sake I'll do't:
let me entreat the corpse to be set down.

sp.speaker: Sheriff
sp.p: Bearers set down the coffin, — this were wonderful, and worthy Sto's chronicle.

sp.speaker: Pyb.
sp.p: I pray bestow the freedom of the air, upon our wholesome art, — mass, his cheeks begin to receive natural warmth: nay good corporal wake betime, or I shall have a longer sleep than you, — sfoot if he should prove dead indeed now, he were fully revenged upon me for making a property on him, yet I had rather run upon the ropes, then have the rope like a tetter run upon me, o — he stirs — he stirs again — look gentlemen, he recovers, he starts, he rises.

sp.speaker: Sheriff
sp.p: O, o, defend us — out alas.

sp.speaker: Pyb.
sp.p: Nay pray be still; you'll make him more giddy else, — he knows nobody yet.

sp.speaker: Corporal
sp.p: Zounds: who am I? covered with snow? I marvel?

sp.speaker: Pyb.
sp.p: Nay I knew he would swear the first thing he did, as soon as ever he came to his life again.

sp.speaker: Corporal
sp.p: Sfoot hostess — some hot porridge, — o, o, lay on a dozen of faggots in the moon parlour, there.

sp.speaker: Pyb.
sp.p: Lady, you must needs take a little pity of him i'faith, and send him in to your kitchen fire.

sp.speaker: Widow
sp.p: O, with all my heart sir, Nicholas and frailty, help to bear him in.

sp.speaker: Nich.
sp.p: Bear him in, qua than, pray call out the maids, I shall ne'er have the heart to do't indeed la.

sp.speaker: Frai.
sp.p: Not I neither, I cannot abide to handle a ghost of all me.

sp.speaker: Corporal
sp.p: 'Sblood, let me see, where was I drunk last night, heh —

sp.speaker: Widow
sp.p: O, shall I bid you once again take him away.

sp.speaker: Frai.
sp.p: Why, we're as fearful as you I warrant you — o —

sp.speaker: Widow
sp.p: Away villains, bid the maids make him a caudle presently to settle his brain, — or a posset of sack, quickly, quickly.

sp.speaker: Skir.
sp.p: Sir, whatsoe'er you are, I do more than admire you.

sp.speaker: Widow
sp.p: O ay, if you knew all master sheriff, as you shall do, you would say then, that here were two of the rarest men within the walls of Christendom

sp.speaker: Sheriff
sp.p: Two of 'em, oh wonderful: officers I discharge you, set him free all's in tune.

sp.speaker: Sir Godf.
sp.p: I and a banquet ready by this time master sheriff, to which I most cheerfully invite you, and your late prisoner there? see you this goodly chain sir, must, no more words, 'twas lost, a dis found again; come my inestimable bullies, we'll talk of your noble acts in sparkling Charnico, and in stead of a jester, we'll ha' the ghost ith' white sheet sit at upper end a'th table.

sp.speaker: Sheriff.
sp.p: Exc'llent merry man i'faith.

sp.speaker: Frank
sp.l: Well, seeing I am enjoined to love and marry.
My foolish vow thus I cashier to air
Which first begotten it, — now love play thy part;
The scholar reads his lecture in my heart.

div.head: Actus 5. Scen. 1.
div.stage: Enter in haste master Edmund and frailty.

sp.speaker: Ed.
sp.p: This is the marriage morning for my mother and my sister.

sp.speaker: Frail.
sp.p: O me master Edmund we shall ha' rare doings.

sp.speaker: Ed.
sp.p: Nay go frailty run to the sexton, you know my mother will be married at saint Antling's, hie thee, 'tis passed five, bid them open the church door, my sister is almost ready.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.p: What all ready master Edmond.

sp.speaker: Ed.
sp.p: Nay go hie thee first run to the sexton, and run to the clerk and then run to master Pigman the parson, and then run to the milliner, and then run home again.

sp.speaker: Frail.
sp.p: Here's run, run, run —

sp.speaker: Ed.
sp.p: But hark frailty:

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.p: What more yet?

sp.speaker: Edm.
sp.p: Has the maids remembered to strew the way to the church.

sp.speaker: Frail.
sp.p: Fagh an hour ago I help 'em myself.

sp.speaker: Ed.
sp.p: Away, away, away, away then.

sp.speaker: Frail.
sp.p: Away, away, away then

sp.speaker: Edm.
sp.p:
I shall have a simple father in-law, a brave captain able to beat all our street: captain idle, now my lady mother will be fit for a delicate name, my lady idle, my lalie idle, the finest name that can be for a woman, and then the scholar master Pie-board for my sister Francis, that will be
mistress Francis Pie-board, mistress Francis Pie-boord, they'll keep a good table I warrant you, now all the knights noses are put out of joint, they may go to a bone setters now. Enter captain and pie-boord.hark, hark o who comes here with two torches before 'em, my sweet captain, and my fine scholar, o, how bravely they are shot up in one night, they look like fine Britons now methinks , here's a gallant change i'faith slid they have hired men and all by the clock.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: Master Edmund, kind, honest, dainty master Edmond.

sp.speaker: Edm.
sp.p: Fogh, sweet captain father in-law a rare perfume i'faith.

sp.speaker: Pie.
sp.p: What are the brides stirring? may we steal upon 'em thinkst thou master Edmond.

sp.speaker: Edm.
sp.p: Faw, there e'en upon red dines I can assure you? for they were at there torch e'en now, by the same token I tumbled down the stairs.

sp.speaker: Pie.
sp.p: Alas poor master Edmond.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: O the musicians I pray the master Edmond call 'em in and liquor 'em a little.

sp.speaker: Ed.
sp.p: That I will sweet captain father in law and make each of them as drunk as a common fiddler.

div.stage: Enter sir John Penidub, and Moll above lacing of her clothes.

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.p: Whewh mistress Moll, mistress Moll.

sp.speaker: Mol.
sp.p: Who's there?

sp.speaker: Mol.
sp.p: Who sir John penidub oh you're an early cock i'faith, who would have thought you to be so rare a stirrer.

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.p: Prithee Moll let me come up.

sp.speaker: Mol.
sp.p: No by my faith sir John, I'll keep you down, for you knights are very dangerous if once you get above.

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.p: I'll not stay i'faith.

sp.speaker: Mol.
sp.p:
I'faith you shall stay, for sir John you must note the nature of the climates your Northern wench in her own country may well hold out till she be fifteen,
but if she touch the South once, and up to London, here the chimes go presently after twelve.

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.p: O th' art a mad wench Moll, but I pray thee make haste, for the priest is gone before.

sp.speaker: Moll.
sp.p: Do you follow him, I'll not be long after.

div.stage: Enter sir Oliver Muckhill, sir Andrew Tipstaff, and old skirmish talking.

sp.speaker: Muck.
sp.p: O monstrous unheard of forgery.

sp.speaker: Tipstaff
sp.p: Knight, I never heard of such villainy in our own country, in my life.

sp.speaker: Muck.
sp.p: Why 'tis impossible, dare you maintain your words?

sp.speaker: Skir.
sp.p: Dare we? e'en to their wezen pipe;, we know all their plots, they cannot squander with us, they have knavishly abused us, made only properties on's to advance their selves upon our shoulders, but they shall rue their abuses, this morning they are to be married.

sp.speaker: Muck.
sp.p: 'Tis too true, yet if the widow be not too much besotted on slights and forgeries, the revelation of their villainies will make 'em loathsome, and to that end, be it in private to you, I sent late last night to an honourable personage, to whom I am much indebted in kindness, as he is to me, and therefore presume upon the payment of his tongue, and that he will lay out good words for me, and to speak truth, for such needful occasions, I only preserve him in bond, and sometimes he may do me more good here in the city by a free word of his mouth, then if he had paid one half in hand, and took doomsday for t' other.

sp.speaker: Tipstaff
sp.p: In troth sir, without soothing be it spoken, you have published much judgement in these few words.

sp.speaker: Muck.
sp.p: For you know, what such a man utters will be thought effectual and to weighty purpose, and therefore into his mouth we'll put the approved theme of their forgeries.

sp.speaker: Skir.
sp.p: And I'll maintain it knight, if she'll be true.

sp.speaker: Muck.
sp.p: How now fellow.

sp.speaker: Servant
sp.p: May it please you sir, my lord is newly lighted from his coach.

sp.speaker: Muc.
sp.l: Is my lord come already; his honours early,
You see he loves me well up before seven,
Trust me I have found him night capped at a eleven,
There's good hope yet; come Jee relate all to him.

div.stage: Enter the two bridegroom's captain and scholar after them, sir Godfrey and Edmond, widow change in apparel, mistress Francis led between two knights, sir John Pennydub and

sp.speaker: Moll:
sp.p: There meets them a noble man, sir Oliver Muckil, and sir Andrew tipstaff.

sp.speaker: Noble
sp.p: By your leave lady.

sp.speaker: Widow
sp.p: My lord your honour is most chastely welcome,

sp.speaker: Noble
sp.p: Madam though I came now from court, I come not to flatter you: upon whom can I justly cast this blot, but upon your own forehead, that know not ink from milk such is the blind besotting in the state of an unheaded woman that's a widow. For it is the property of all you that are widows (A hand full excepted) to hate those that honestly and carefully love you, to the maintenance of credit state and posterity, and strongly to dote on those, that only love you to undo you who regard you least are best regarded, who hate you most are best beloved, and if there be but one man amongst ten thousand millions of men that is accursed disastrous and evilly planeted whom fortune beats most, whom God hates most, and all societies esteem least, that man is sure to be a husband — such is the peevish moon that rules you bloods. An impudent fellow best woes you, a flattering lip best wins you, or in a mirth who talks roughliest is most sweetest, nor can you distinguish truth, from forgeries, mists from simplicity, witness those two deceitful monsters that you have entertained for bridegrooms.

sp.speaker: Widow
sp.p: Deceitful.

sp.speaker: Pie.
sp.p: All will out.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: Sfoot who has blabbed George? that foolish Nicholas.

sp.speaker: Noble
sp.p: For what they have besotted you easy blood withal, wear naught but forgeries, the fortune telling for husbands, the conjuring for the chain, sir Godfrey heard the falsehood of all: nothing but mere knavery deceit and cozenage.

sp.speaker: Widow
sp.p:
O wonderful, indeed I wondered that my husband with
all his craft could nor keep himself out of purgatory.

sp.speaker: Sir Godf.
sp.p: And I more wonder that my chain should be gone and my tailor had none of it.

sp.speaker: Mol.
sp.p: And I wondered most of all that I, should be tied from marriage having such a mind to't, come s. John Pennydub, fair weather on our side the moon has changed since yesternight .

sp.speaker: Pie.
sp.p: The sting of every evil is within me.

sp.speaker: Noble
sp.p: And that you may perceive I feign not with you, behold their fellow actor in those forgeries who full of spleen and envy at their so sudden advancements revealed all there plot in anger.

sp.speaker: Pie.
sp.p: Base soldier to reveal us.

sp.speaker: Widow
sp.p: Is't possible we should be blinded so and our eyes open

sp.speaker: Noble
sp.p: Widow will you now believe that false, which to soon you believed true.

sp.speaker: Widow
sp.p: O to my shame I do.

sp.speaker: Sir Godf.
sp.p: But under favour my lord my chain was truly lost and strangely found again.

sp.speaker: Noble
sp.p: Resolve him of that soldier,

sp.speaker: Sir.
sp.p: In few words knight then, thou wert the arch-gull of all.

sp.speaker: Sir Godf.
sp.p: God how sir.

sp.speaker: Skir.
sp.p: Nay I'll prove it: for the chain was but hidden in the rosemary bank all this while, and thou got'st him out of prison to conjure for it who did it admirably fustianly, for indeed what need any others when he knew where it was.

sp.speaker: Sir Godf.
sp.p: O vilainy of villainies, but how came my chain there

sp.speaker: Skir,
sp.p: Where's truly la, in deed la, he that will not swear, but lie, he that will not steal, but rob: pure Nicholas saint Antling's.

sp.speaker: Sir Godf.
sp.l: O villain one of our society,
Deemed always holy, pure, religious,
A Puritan? A thief, when wast ever hard?
Sooner we'll kill a man then steal thou knowest,
Out slave I'll rend my lion from thy back — with mine own hands.

sp.speaker: Nich.
sp.l: Dear master, o.

sp.speaker: Noble
sp.l: Nay knight dwell in patience,
sp.p:
And now widow being so near the church, 'twere great pity, nay uncharity to send you home again without a husband,
draw nearer you of true worship, state and credit, that should not stand so far off from a widow, and suffer forged shapes to come between you, not that in these, I blemish the true title of a captain, or blot the fair margin of a scholar; for I honour worthy and deserving parts in the one, and cherish fruitful virtues in the other. Come lady, and you virgin bestow your eyes and your purest affections, upon me of estimation both in court and city, that hath long wooed you, and both with there hearts and wealth sincerely love you.

sp.speaker: Sir Godf.
sp.p: Good sister do: sweet little Frank, these are men of reputation, you shall be welcome at court: a great credit for a citizen sweet sister.

sp.speaker: Noble
sp.p: Come her silence does consent to't.

sp.speaker: Widow
sp.p: I know not with what face,

sp.speaker: Noble
sp.p: Pah pah why with your own face they desire no other.

sp.speaker: Widow
sp.p: Pardon me worthy sirs, I and my daughter have wronged your loves.

sp.speaker: Muck.
sp.l: 'Tis easily pardoned lady,
If you vouch safe it now.

sp.speaker: Widow
sp.p: With all my soul,

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: And I with all my heart,

sp.speaker: Moll.
sp.p: And I sir John with soul, heart, lights and all.

sp.speaker: Sir oh
sp.l: They are all mine Moll.

sp.speaker: Noble
sp.l: Now lady?
What honest spirit but will applaud your choice,
And gladly furnish you with hand and voice,
A happy change which makes e'en heaven rejoice,
Come enter into your loys, you shall not want,
For fathers now, I doubt it not believe me,
But that you shall have hands enough to give.

div.head: Textual Notes
div.p: The textual notes below aim at making textual corrections readable in their immediate context and facilitating access to the source text. A five-dit number preceded by 'A' or 'B' represents an EEBO-TCP filenumber. A notation like "6-b-2890" means "look for EEBO page image 6 of that text, word 289 on the right side of the double-page image." That reference is followed by the corrupt reading. A black dot stands for an unidentified letter, a black square for an unidentified punctuation mark, a diamond for a missing word, and the ellipsis for a short span of undefined length. The corrected reading is displayed as a kewyord in context.
